âI move:

motion.para: That this House:
(1) notes that 24 311 Social Security recipients have their compensation preclusion period spanning the introduction of the GST;
(2) notes that the average length of preclusion periods is 291 weeks;
(3) notes that the income cut-out rate has increased by $115.23 per week to compensate for price rises caused by the GST;
(4) notes that if the post GST cut-out rate of $543.63 was applied to the post GST portion of the preclusion period it would result in a significant reduction in the preclusion period; and
(5) condemns the Government's failure to introduce legislation to extend GST compensation to people whose compensation preclusion period spans the introduction of the GST.

speech.para: When the government introduced the GST, against the wishes of the vast majority of Australian people, they put in place a number of compensation measures. These measures have proved to be completely inadequate, but at least the government acknowledged that the GST would hurt and tried to do something to offset that. This motion is about a group of people who were forgotten about: a group who missed out on the GST related compensation and who are doing it very tough as a result.

If you are injured in an accident, whether on our roads, at work or at somewhere like a restaurant or shopping centre, you are entitled to claim compensation. Any compensation payout is usually made up of two components. The first is for pain and suffering and the second is for loss of income if you are unable to work as a consequence of your injury. If you are granted compensation, a consequence is that you are precluded from obtaining Centrelink benefits for a certain period of time. What Centrelink does to determine the length of the preclusion period is to take the economic loss component of the payout and divide it by a figure determined from time to time which reflects living expenses. The resultant number is the number of weeks for which a person is precluded from claiming benefits. Prior to 1 July last year, when the GST was introduced, that figure was $428.40.

I will give hypothetical examples to illustrate what is wrong with the current arrangement. Take worker Aâwe will call him Johnâas an example. If John had an accident on 1 January 2000 and, as a result, was unable to continue working, he would have received a compensation payout. Let us say he received a payment where the economic loss component was $100,000. John would then have been precluded from claiming Centrelink benefits for just over 233 weeksâthat is, nearly 4Â½ years. He would be expected to live on that figure until around the middle of June 2004.

Let us now compare that worker with worker Bâ we will call her Betty. If Betty had a similar accident six months later, on 1 July 2000, and received the same compensation payout for economic loss of $100,000, then the story would be very different. As part of the government's recognition that the GST would hurt many people, as I have said, they have implemented some compensation measures. One of the measures introduced was to raise that preclusion period cut-out figure from $428.40 to $543.63. So Betty received the same $100,000 economic loss component as John, but her preclusion period under the new figure would have been 184 weeks, or just over 3Â½ years. Betty would be entitled to claim Centrelink benefits in January 2004, almost six months before John. Of course, John had already been laid up and unable to work for six months before Betty was even injured.

Does that sound fair? Is it fair that the first injured worker, John, would have to live almost a full year, 49 weeks, longer than Betty on the same amount of money? Is it fair that John was injured six months before Betty and yet cannot claim benefits until six months after she is able to? I do not think it is fair at all, and that is why I put this motion on the Notice Paper. If the GST compensation that the government recognised was necessary had been extended to John, we would see a bit more fairness in the scheme. If the new income cut-out figure of $543.63 was applied to that portion of the compensation payment left after 1 July, John would not be facing 49 weeks longer than Betty at all; the figure would be closer to only five weeks longer.

I will stop using hypothetical examplesâthey were simply to illustrate the unfairness of the system and the lack of adequate compensation to those already in the system. How many were in the system; how many accident victims had their preclusion period span the introduction of the GST? How many real people are in the same situation as the hypothetical examples? I asked the minister this in question No. 2370, the answer to which was given on 2 April this year. There were 24,311 people whose preclusion period spanned the introduction of the GSTâthat is, 24,311 people in the same boat as our hypothetical worker A: laid up, unable to work and facing a long time before benefits can be claimed.

A number of these 24,000 people are constituents of mine. I first raised this issue in a grievance debate in October last year when I spoke about a constituent, David Lambert. Mr Lambert was injured in a car accident and received a court settlement of $90,000, with an economic loss component estimated at $45,000. This meant he was precluded from Centrelink payments for 106 weeks, from 27 October 1999 until 6 November 2001âa period spanning the introduction of the GST. So almost nine months or 35 per cent of this constituent's preclusion period fell before the introduction of the GST and 23 months or 65 per cent fell post GST. But his preclusion period is based entirely on the lower, pre-GST income cut-out rate. If we were able to take the post-GST proportion of Mr Lambert's payout and apply the post-GST cut-out figure of $543.63âin other words, if we were to extend to him the compensation that the government thought necessary for everybody elseâMr Lambert would not have to wait until November to claim Centrelink benefits again. He could have done so on 26 July, some 15 weeks before his current date.

Another constituent of mine has a preclusion period that goes until the end of June 2014. He is expected to live for the next 13 years on that figure of $428.40 per week because he has not been compensated for the GST. This means he is effectively living on $115 less per week than somebody who is injured today and who would be living on $543 per week. If the GST compensation were extended to my constituent, he would be able to claim benefits again around June 2011, some three years earlier. I urge the minister to think about these three years that my constituent has to live without access to benefits that he would have been entitled to had he been properly compensated for the GST.

In part (7) of that question, I asked the minister why he would not introduce legislation to extend the GST compensation to people who were caught up in that situation, having their preclusion period spanning the introduction of the GST. His answer was, `No, for the reasons given above,' which I took to mean his answer to parts (3) and (6). In his answer to part (3), he said:

quote.para: The Social Security Act 1991 does not provide for a compensation preclusion period to be divided into pre and post GST portions.

speech.para: Obviously not. That is the reason for this private member's motion, and that is why we want legislation introduced to take account of the GST's impact. The minister seems to have missed the point on that one. He may also have been referring to his answer in part (6), in which he said:

quote.para: It would require an exhaustive, manual examination of more than 24,000 files with a significant resource impost on Centrelink and cannot be justified.

speech.para: That is not the case, however. A simple formula on an Excel spreadsheet would tell him exactly what he needs to know. My office created such a spreadsheet in about 10 minutes. I seek leave to table that spreadsheet.
Leave granted.

talk.start.para: âI have clearly said that people who were injured prior to the introduction of the GST and those whose injuries spanned the introduction of the GST are clearly at a disadvantage compared with those who were injured after the introduction of the GST. I urge the House to support the motion. (Time expired)
(Mr Jenkins)âIs the motion seconded?
âI second the motion and reserve my right to speak at a later time.

âI listened carefully to my friend the member for Greenway, who has great concern for people's wellbeing and is notoriously compassionate and thoughtful. He is no soft touch, however; he does his homework carefully when he looks at people's needs. I thank him for moving the motion and for giving us an opportunity to explore some ideas that he has gleaned from his experience with his constituents in regard to the impact of the GST on lump sum compensation recipients. The member is breaking new ground, as he is no doubt aware, because traditionally it has never been the process of the welfare system in Australia to fluctuate with regard to things such as compensation. Welfare payments are designed to underpin people's income and circumstances no matter what the fluctuations of other benefits or entitlements may be. A change in compensation payments, a change in the tax system or an adjustment by the government according to average male weekly earnings are other factors that impact on the calculations that the member has described. Half-yearly changes in welfare payments also impact on the extent to which a compensation package will last a recipient.

speech.para: I do not know that the member went as far as proposing that every time there is a variation of that type the Commonwealth should recalculate its welfare payments for compensation recipients, but implicit in what he said is that there should be an adjustment when there are any changes. One of the most significant changes introduced by this government has been the introduction of legislation to ensure that pensions do not fall below 25 per cent of male total average weekly earnings. That is seldom acknowledged by the other side of the House, but it is a significant increase to all welfare recipients that should have produce an element of change when people calculate the duration of their workers compensation payments.

Legislative amendments result in different treatment for compensation recipients, which is dependent upon the date they receive their compensation payment or the type of social security payment they have claimed. The complexity of what the member proposes is very significant, but I understand the thoughtful basis of it. If people who receive a compensation lump sum feel they are experiencing hardship or special circumstances, they can ask for a review of their situation under the hardship clause. I am sure that the honourable member is aware of those provisions. There is an underpinning or a propping-up under section 1184 of the Social Security Act. People can ask for such a review by contacting their Centrelink office or working through members of parliament. A process is in place to claim benefits if a person falls on hardship or says that they are experiencing harsh times. When I looked at that provision, I wondered what other provisions the government has made that will affect people who may be on compensation or on welfare payments. The extension of the Commonwealth seniors health card to 270,000 older Australians will pick up people who are on compensation payments or who have access to part pensions.

Some $146 million is going to a fair go for mature workers. That will give people aged 50 and over encouragement to participate in the work force. That is an encouragement for some people who have had an accident and been damaged and who feel that they do not know how they are ever going to manage. However, gradually they make some recovery or find, in these days of computers, that there is a role for them to fill and that they can play a very significant part in society. The government is supporting that process, even to the extent of $177 million over four years for a better deal for people with disabilities. That also impacts on people who may be partly disabled because of an accident and who are on compensation payments.

Getting the right people to help is another program, involving $144 million over four years to provide the right help for disadvantaged people through better assessment, providing significant assistance in their homes and appropriate help for those with severe or multiple non-vocational barriers to participating. These are all most significant changes that complement and supplement the underpinning of the not less than 25 per cent of average male weekly earnings. That is part of what the government has done to assist those people who may have suffered an accident.

There are also provisions for accident victims or those on compensation payments to provide more child-care places. There will be $15 million over four years for that covering outside of school hour places. That is an excellent program to provide assistance to parents in need, who need that additional relief from their household responsibilities. Helping parents to return to work is another assistance program designed specifically for people who may be suffering a disability or some impediment to working. Helping people to find jobs involves $296 million over four years, better employment services, new training credits and helping people to participate. There is a community and business engagement program and $521 million to help people to generate a working credit.

All of that is very significant. At the same time, they all ensure that people are not ripping off the system. Since we have been in officeâand I have not heard any complaints about thisâthis government has saved taxpayers $1 billion by careful application of guidelines and rules so that people must live within the circumstances of the benefits that the Commonwealth is paying. This is a process of a safety net and support; it is not a hammock for people to rest in and take life easy. It is support for people who are really in need. This government has done that. It has also implemented a program of a waiting period before migrants can receive social welfare. Most migrants will have to wait up to two years before they become eligible for a welfare assessment.

When I look at the total picture of what the honourable member has raised in the House today, I consider it very thoughtful, and very helpful for us to consider. It is a process which could easily escape the attention of the House. I think that it is a program of adjustment that he wants to see introduced which is complex and difficult to make assessments on because of the before and after factors of the GST. I will take some interest in the spreadsheet, which I would have liked to have seen before the debate, but I will look at it after the debate and see how simple the member's claims are because he said that it is a simple process. I believe him and I will look at it.

Finally, the complexities worry me. A broad range of programs has been instigated recently to assist people with disabilities and who are suffering disablement in the workplace. That is the action of a government which is determined to make sure that people do not fall through the cracks, that they are properly attended to and that their needs are well looked after. Underpinning all that, of course, if that fails there is the hardship claim that people can make through Centrelink to prevent them from being completely destitute. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI congratulate the member for Greenway on bringing this most important motion to the House. The goods and services tax which came into operation in July last year has sent a shock wave through the Australian community. Some impacts of the GST were expected and some allowances were made. In the last budget, we saw more changes to taxation and social security arrangements in an attempt to restore equity. One measure in the original GST package was seen to benefit some people receiving social security benefits. This was an increase in the income cut out amount that allowed for some benefit to be paid up to that amount. Before the introduction of the GST in July 2000, this cut out figure was $428.40 per week. Because it was necessary to compensate pensioners for the loss of the purchasing power of their benefit, the income cut out amount was raised to $543.63. That is a big increaseâin fact, nearly 27 per cent. It should give some idea of the impact of the GST on pensioners.

speech.para: While this helped some pensioners, one group in the community can quite rightly claim to have missed out as a result of that increase. People who received a lump sum settlement as compensation for injuries which have resulted in the loss of work opportunities are now treated differently depending on the date of their injury. Anyone suffering an injury before the introduction of the GST is much worse off than someone injured after that date because the income cut out amount is used to calculate the length of time that someone who has received a lump sum must wait before they can access a benefit. The difference in amounts leads to different periods which people must wait.

This is unfair. It is an unintended consequence of the goods and services tax compensation arrangements, but one which this government has refused to set right. As a result, some 24,000 people are forced to wait much longer before they can access social security benefits simply because they were injured before 1 July 2000. This is most unfair, but to show just how unfair it is let me give the House an example of the difference the increased income cut-out amount makes to an individual.

Let me take someone on the average preclusion period of 291 weeks. Using the pre-GST divisor, 291 weeks, or about 5Â½ years, would result from a lump sum of just under $125,000. Using the post-GST divisor, a person receiving a lump sum of $125,000 would have a preclusion period of only 229 weeksâthat is, less than 4Â½ years. That is a difference of 62 weeks or well over one year. If you took two people, one injured on 30 June 2000 and the other injured on 1 July 2000, and both received $125,000, the one injured on 1 July would be able to access a benefit more than one year earlier than the person injured the day before.

This is grossly unfair, and this government refuses to make the relatively minor changes to the Social Security Act to make it fair for all. We are dealing here with people who have suffered serious injuryâpeople whose lives have been shattered as a result of those injuries. There are of course hardship provisions in the Social Security Act, but would it not be easier to recalculate the preclusion period in a fairer way? We are dealing with around 24,000 cases, but that is, after all, just about 160 people in each federal electorate. I know that many people in this position are poorly advised and do not fully understand how their lump sum settlement will affect their future entitlements, but I am sure they expect to be treated fairly. I doubt that the courts have taken into consideration the different treatment of post-GST accident victims. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI, too, rise to speak on the motion that has been moved by the member for Greenway and again congratulate him. Over the last three years in particular I have gained a great deal of respect for him in this place. The motion opens up a whole range of issues with regard to compensation, and I particularly want to have a look at workers compensation. I will look at it a little bit from the other end of things. It has obviously been the view of Commonwealth governments that the primary responsibility for the support of people who have suffered from compensable illness or injury rests with the relevant state or territory compensation schemes and not with the taxpayer funded social security system. I think that needs to be said up front: state or territory compensation schemes generally provide more long-term earnings related payments than the social security system would be able to provide.

speech.para: Coming out of small business as I do, the dramatic increases in the costs of the provision of workers compensation have been of great concern to me and to colleagues of mine in small business, particularly when you compare what is happening in New South Wales with Queensland, for example, and as they relate to rural and agricultural businesses based in country Australia. I want to give some comparisons of the rates applicable in New South Wales with the rates that are being paid in Queensland and give some of the percentages of difference. I have just picked a number of the workers compensation rates off the New South Wales farmers web site that I found when I was looking into this issue.

One of the issues that affects my area of New England in particular is grain growing. In New South Wales the workers compensation rate for 2001-02 is 11.13 per centâup six per centâcompared with Queensland, which has a rate of 2.26 per cent. The cost to insure in New South Wales is nearly 500 per cent greater than in Queensland. If you compare the combined grain growing, sheep farming and beef cattle farming rate, in New South Wales it is 12.1 per cent, which is up 15 per cent, and in Queensland it is 3.86 per cent. It is a significant difference; in fact, the cost in New South Wales is nearly three times the cost in Queensland.

Getting closer to the higher country, for sheep farming the rate is 12.1 per centâthat again is an increase of 15 per cent. In Queensland for sheep farming it is 4.26 per cent. The New South Wales rate is 284 per cent more than the Queensland rate. These are all things that are adding to the costs for small business. The compensation rate for beef cattle farming in New South Wales is 10.19 per cent as against 5.43 per cent in Queenslandâagain, nearly double. For beef feedlotsâand I am fortunate enough have a couple in my electorate which provide tremendous employment opportunitiesâthe compensation rate in New South Wales is 10.19 per cent and in Queensland it is 5.43 per cent. Again, you can see the significant increases that workers compensation costs businesses in New South Wales when compared with Queensland. In poultry and meat farming, the rate is now 7.2 per cent. It is also up 15 per cent, which is 238 per cent higher than it is in Queensland, where the rate is only 3.02 per cent. When we look at reforms that were going to be done in New South Wales for workers compensation, we know that the Carr Labor government has failed. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: (Mr Hawker)âOrder! The time allotted for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will made an order of the day for the next sitting. The member for New England will have an opportunity to continue speaking when the debate is resumed.
âI move:

motion.para: That this House:
(1) commends the Australian Government on its moves to establish a whale sanctuary at the most recent meeting of the International Whaling Commission in London;
(2) records its regret that the motion was defeated after failing to receive the required 75 per cent backing from member states;
(3) calls on those states who abstained or voted against the motion to review their positions in order to allow this important initiative to proceed.

talk.start.para: (Mr Hawker)âIs the motion seconded?
âI second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

âLast month delegates from 43 of the member states of the International Whaling Commission met in London to review the global moratorium on whaling and to consider establishing further whale sanctuaries. The Australian government led the way at this last meeting of the IWC, seeking the formation of a whale sanctuary in the South Pacific. Such a sanctuary is not a new or revolutionary idea and follows the examples of the Indian Ocean sanctuary established in 1979 and the Southern Ocean sanctuary established in 1994. As the House would be aware, for the second year in a row this motion failed because it failed to obtain the three-quarters majority required by IWC regulations for a motion to be passed.

speech.para: In terms of the voting pattern for the sanctuary, among the 19 other nations who voted with Australia for the sanctuary were: New Zealand, Great Britain, the United States, South Africa and numerous nations from Europe and South America. Against the sanctuary were 13 nations, including Japan and Norway, as well as, rather unusually, six eastern Caribbean states that one would logically assume had little interest in blocking such a sanctuary due to their lack of any commercial whaling industry in their countries. The six states were Antigua & Barbuda, Dominica, Grenada, St Lucia, St Vincent and the Grenadines and St Kitts-Nevis. Four nations abstained from the voting. Those countries were Ireland, Oman, Morocco and the Solomon Islands.

It should be noted that the vote was tainted by allegations of vote buying and that Japan had threatened that aid for some of the poorer countriesâparticularly those Caribbean statesâwould be withdrawn if they did not oppose the sanctuary. These allegations were given further momentum by the admission of the head of Japan's fisheries, Maseyuku Komatsu, on the ABC's ForeignCorrespondent program in mid-July that Japan saw development aid as a `major tool' in ensuring that developing countries vote in favour of whaling at IWC meetings. The same program saw Mr Komatsu make the extraordinary comment that minke whales are the `cockroaches of the ocean'.

Allegations of vote buying must be treated with caution, however, particularly as they have been denied by the Japanese government. I commend environment minister Senator Hill's refusal to resort to vilification and accusation in the light of strong views expressed by other parties following the vote. Comments made in the heat of the moment could do considerable damage to future hopes for a sanctuary and the minister's actions were considered and sensible. Nevertheless, utmost caution must be exercised to ensure that meetings of the IWC do not degenerate into some cynical vote stacking exercise for the developed countries. Conversely, it must not become a vehicle for the less developed nations to ensure their flow of aid continues or to draw attention to unrelated issues.

So why have a sanctuary? There are a number of reasons why I strongly believe that the international community should endorse a South Pacific Whale Sanctuary. Firstly, in relation to whale populations, it cannot be denied that the international moratorium on commercial whaling that has been in place since the hunting season of 1985-86 has had a major positive effect on whale populations around the world, as have the two sanctuaries already in existence. Prior to the 1985-86 season, technological progress in locational and harpoon technology had seen whales hunted to within a few years of extinction. Even after 15 years of moratorium, the blue and northern right whales remain on the endangered list, while the bowhead, southern right, sei, fin and humpback whales are all classified as vulnerable. Current estimates place the population of blue whales in the South Pacific anywhere between 400 and 1,400, while the IWC is unable to provide a number of minke whales in the area.

In relation to tourism, I believe there is a lot of merit in the argument of tourism operators from all South Pacific nations in favour of the sanctuary. In New South Wales alone there are eight tourist operators drawing their income from whale watching and related activities between Jervis Bay and Eden alone. Each of these operators is bringing in tens of thousands of dollars for their local economies up and down the coast. Up in Hervey Bay in Queensland, each visit by a humpback whale is valued at approximately $100,000. These figures are similar for other Pacific nations who would benefit from a safe haven leading to increased whale sightings.
The third aspect is in relation to cruelty. Steven Brook, the science writer for the Australian newspaper, recently noted:

quote.para: There is no humane way of doing it.

speech.para: that is, killing whalesâ

quote.para: Whalers try to pierce their hearts with thin harpoons called lances, but whales can take up to 20 minutes to die, often drowning in their blood.

speech.para: While not wishing to impose my views on the cruelty or otherwise of whaling onto the communities of Japan, the establishment of a sanctuary in this part of the world would make it clear that the practice is no longer condoned here.

Fourthly, there is Australia's example, and that is our own experience. In the past we have been able to pull back from our own heavy reliance on whaling as an industry. In fact, whaling was this country's first primary industry: we killed around 26,000 southern right whales and 40,000 humpbacks over 100 years of whaling, it is estimated. Despite this, we have introduced protective areas as far back as 1935, despite the difficulty it caused to some whaling communities. We have also always been one of the IWC's most vocal and active members. In this light, the arguments of other whaling countries about the effects on their way of life and economies are less compelling.

Fifthly, in relation to why we should support this motion, there is unanimous support in the South Pacific region for such a sanctuary. At the meeting of the 16-nation Pacific Island Forum in Nauru 10 days ago, all member states agreed that they should continue to pursue the whaling free sanctuary in the South Pacific. While the sanctuary would cover waters belonging to all nations in the world, the fact remains that local nations are opposed to whaling of any form taking place in their backyards. Countries that continue to push for a return to commercial whaling should respect our combined wish.

By way of conclusion, several days after the IWC meeting wound up in London, Japan's whaling fleet returned to port with their scientific catch of 158 whalesâalmost double the amount they had taken at the same time last year. Their cargo included 100 minke whales, 50 bryde's whales and eight sperm whales and had a commercial value of millions and millions of dollars. Despite being classified under Japan's scientific whaling allocation, these whales will still go on sale at Tokyo's fish markets, servicing the market and demand for whale products in that country. That this is allowed to occur despite the international ban on commercial whaling suggests that the situation as it stands is obviously not enough.

A South Pacific whale sanctuary would reflect the desire of countries in this part of the world to protect these endangered animals and local industries. The Australian government should be congratulated on taking a strong stand and on lobbying support, at the recent International Whaling Commission meeting in London, for the establishment of a whale sanctuary in the South Pacific. The work done by Minister Robert Hill and the Department of the Environment and Heritage has been very positive in terms of promoting the protection of whales and the recognition of their importance to the community. The Australian community recognises that whales are an endangered species and need to be protected, and this government have shown leadership on this important issue.

I record our regret that we did not get the two-thirds majority which was needed. If it had been due to lack of support from major countries around the world, we would have said, `That is tough; these things happen.' But it is of concern that very tiny countries that have had no significant involvement in whaling have made all types of suggestions as to why they voted the way they did. We do not wish to make any allegations of impropriety, but it does seem very unusual. We recognise that Japan has a strong interest in continuing to harvest whales, but most developed countries around the world agree that we should try to preserve the whales. We call on those countries which abstained or voted against the motion to reconsider in order to ensure that the South Pacific does remain a sanctuary for whales. Whales are some of the most wonderful creatures on this earth and should be preserved long into the future.

talk.start.para: âI am pleased to support the motion concerning a whale sanctuary in the South Pacific. Today I want to speak about the events that took place at the annual meeting of the International Whaling Commission which were held in July this year. It was an important gathering of both pro-whaling and antiwhaling factions. The discussions centred on the future management of the world's whales and focused on the general seafood consumption of whales, the coastal allocation of Minke whales, and related management schemes. But perhaps the most significant focus was the discussion about the proposal to establish a whale sanctuary in the Pacific.

speech.para: I would like to speak about issues which were raised about the proposed sanctuary and to record my disappointment with the outcome. However, before I speak further on that matter, I am proud to say that Australia did play a leading role in lobbying for this initiative. I would like to take this opportunity to support the motion and commend the government for taking this position on behalf of the Australian people. I also extend my thanks to our New Zealand counterparts, who lobbied with an equal and unwavering dedication. For those nations that abstained or voted against the motion, I call on the House to restate Australia's position in the hope that they will review their decisions and allow this initiative to proceed next year.

Despite our failure to secure a sanctuary in the Pacific, there is clearly international support for the preservation of whales. The very fact that the recent annual meeting of the International Whaling Commission was its 53rd pays tribute to those attempting to secure a future for the world's whales. It also demonstrates that the future of whaling is an important international issue. Had the plan succeeded, it would have been unique in establishing a regional safe haven. The Pacific sanctuary waters would have extended to adjoin the existing Southern Ocean whale sanctuary and north to the equator. Fiji, Papua New Guinea and 12 South Pacific nations were among the many nations that supported Australia's and New Zealand's attempts to establish this important sanctuary.

I would now like to address the significance of a sanctuary more thoroughly. The concept is not a new one. In 1946, the first whale sanctuary was established by the International Whaling Commission. It is between South America and New Zealand and covers approximately 25 per cent of the Southern Ocean. Between 1979 and 1994, the International Whaling Commission created the Indian Ocean sanctuary and the Southern Ocean sanctuary. Knowing how easy it is to undermine the whale's protection, I believe that it was important for Australia and other nations to take a position at the meeting. Each of our nations has an interest in protecting this endangered marine species.

Protective action has also been taken on a local level. Many of our Pacific neighbours already act individually to protect whales living in and passing through their waters. Others are beginning to engage in bilateral talks in the hope that they will be able to develop legislation to protect future whale populations. However, the most effective means of protecting whales is international regulation. It is in Australia's interests to continue to lobby the international community for regulation in the form of another sanctuary. Australia would have an important role to play in its creation and supervision. From an economic perspective, there are undeniable benefits associated with the establishment of a sanctuary. Already around our shores there is a growing whale-watching industry, and this industry needs to be protected. As people are able to see whales locally, or to travel to a place where whales go past, their knowledge of whales and their needs will be increased and they will feel a much stronger desire to protect the species.

But the argument is not solely an economic one. Australians have a deep commitment to preserving our environment, and, by our very nature, the marine environment is particularly important to us. From this perspective, we have a responsibility to stem the devastating effect that commercial whaling has had on the world's whale population. During the period of unleashed commercial whaling, a number of whale species, including the sei, fin, sperm and bowhead whales, were ruthlessly exploited and their populations took a devastating blow. Unfortunately, the blue and humpback whales are also targeted by whalers and they have never significantly recovered in numbers.

Since the introduction of whaling ships, a large proportion of the world's whale populations have been slaughtered. It is estimated that, by 1975, over 1.5 million whales had been killed. This exploitation has been ruthless. No species is unaffected. Whalers have simply moved on to other species when those that they originally targeted have had their numbers dramatically decreased. It is important that we take a stand against commercial whaling. Of all the other threats facing whales, such as oil exploration, shipping, gas exploration and fishing, commercial whaling is the only one that can be eliminated simply. The way to do this is by holding those nations engaging in commercial whaling accountable for their destructive actions and making them liable for the results that these actions will have. Perhaps if the education program can spread internationally, a number of those countries that engage in commercial whaling will start to see that it is not sustainable and that they should look at minimising this practice, if not stopping it altogether.

It is for this very reason that the International Whaling Commission was assembled. This is an important fact to remember. When the International Whaling Commission was established, it introduced a moratorium on commercial whaling. However, because of the pressure brought to bear by the pro-whaling nations it was not strictly enforced. But, due to the devastating impact that these activities had on the whale population, the moratorium was reintroduced in 1986. Despite this, the moratorium has failed to stop a resurgence in large-scale whaling throughout our global waters. Whales continue to be hunted because countries fail to comply or argue that whaling is necessary for scientific experimentation. I think the credibility of that argument is lacking, and I have met few people who actually agree that it is a sound reason for killing whales. The meat of whales is also being sold as a food delicacy. As a result, nations engaging in these activities continue to aggressively lobby to lift the commercial whaling banâand we must make sure that this never happens. The steps we take must be forward, not backward.

Commercial whaling has never been carried out in a sustainable manner. Its operators have shown a clear disregard for the whale populations and the wider ocean ecosystem. That is why strong measures are now required. We must continue to oppose commercial whaling. Tuna boats that cast long nets are responsible for killing whales. There are environmentally friendly and cost-effective options for tuna boats, and we should not condone any lesser fishing practice when it is having such a devastating impact. There is speculation that other boats that dock in our ports carry out commercial whaling activities. We should not be allowing these ships to dock in Australian ports. By allowing them to dock here, we are in effect supporting their activities.

We should also continue to lobby for the creation of a sanctuary in our territorial waters. I say this because the Southern Ocean sanctuary has clearly been the safest place for whales, with many nations offering it some measure of respect, restraining from undertaking destructive activities in those waters. The deliberations that emerged from the International Whaling Commission meeting make it clear that, if another sanctuary is not created, the world's whale population will be unable to continue their recovery and they will be forced to live among an increasing variety of environmental threats other than commercial whaling. Now is an appropriate time for Australia to renew her commitment to the establishment of a whale sanctuary in our regional waters. I therefore urge this House to renew Australia's commitment to the International Whaling Commission and to the protection of whales. I would also suggest that Australia offer to host next year's annual meeting of the International Whaling Commission in Western Australia, well known for its whale-watching spots. I commend the motion to the House.

talk.start.para: âI am delighted to support the motion moved by the member for Cook for a whale sanctuary in the South Pacific. It is a very worthwhile motion and, Mr Deputy Speaker Hawker, all the more important for the electorate of Wannon, where whale watching in the city of Warrnambool is a very important aspect of your electorate, and also along the Great Ocean Road where the observation of whales is an exciting and interesting pastime for many of our visitors. As you would know, Mr Deputy Speaker, Logan's Beach has almost reached world famous status. Whales go there at the same time every year and visitors can watch their activities. We should re-establish a sustainable whaling industry where whales are looked at rather than harvested. I support the motion for a whale sanctuary on the same basis that I support a sustainable fishing industry, a sustainable forest industry and also because we are very close to the whales in the Southern Ocean being wiped out.

speech.para: As members would be aware, whales feed in two different ways. Some feed on plankton, which are small weeds that whales consume in the southern waters. The killer whale is the only whale that feeds on flesh. Other speakers have mentioned Moby Dick and historic activities that have exterminated whales: harpoon guns, explosive weapons, steam-driven whaling boats and large commercial whaling activities. Whaling was the first primary industry in Australia along the southern coastland. Most members would be aware that whaling was stopped in 1978 by the Fraser government when the Cheynes Beach Whaling Company in Western Australia was closed down. I recall that there was quite a lot of debate at that time. Australia did the right thing at that time and, as the motion says, international groups are not following suit.

I support Australia's endeavours to turn about the 75 per cent vote in the International Whaling Commission to re-establish a whaling sanctuary in the South Pacific. I am indebted to Minister Hill for his statement to the International Whaling Commission. In his statement he made some interesting comments which I would like to support very stronglyâfor example, support for a South Pacific Whale Sanctuary which will complement the Southern Ocean and Indian Ocean sanctuaries. In his statement he goes on to talk about the scientific basis for the sanctuary and opportunities to increase the sustainable use of whale resources as their numbers increase.

Obviously the important aspect of this sanctuary is the whales migrating between their feeding grounds in Antarctica and their calving and breeding grounds in the South Pacific. I understand there is no transfer of the whaling population between the Northern Hemisphere and the Southern Hemisphere, so if we can improve these sanctuaries then we will improve the number of whales that would be reproduced. In the 20th century whaling has taken two million animals from the Southern Hemisphere. Many countries have managed to do that, including Australia and the United States, and there is evidence that secret Soviet whalers also contributed to these quite big numbers of whales being taken for commercial activities.

A really staggering figure is that 200,000 blue whales have been removed from the Southern Ocean; today, according to the scientific community, there are only 1,000 blue whales left in the Southern Hemisphere. On that figure alone we should strongly support the sanctuary in order to allow whale numbers to build up. Over half a million finwhales have been removed from the Southern Ocean, and 30 per cent of the total catch of the Southern Hemisphere's sperm whales have been taken from the South Pacific. So we have a situation where, if the sanctuary is not developed and supported, whale numbers will not build up.

Finally, Japanese whaling expeditions took 158 whales. They claimed it was for a scientific research program. I support other speakers who have said that this is just a disguise for commercial whaling which was banned by the International Whaling Commission in 1987. I strongly support the motion before the parliament on the basis that we will be looking after a mammal which is a very important part of our heritage. More importantly, we need to sustain the reproductive grounds of the whaling population so that they can be returned and to keep an ecosystem operating both in the southern waters and in the proposed sanctuaries.

talk.start.para: âI rise today to support the member for Cook and other members who have already spoken to his private member's motion regarding the attempts of the Australian government to establish a Southern Pacific whale sanctuary. I would like to add my regret to those already expressed in this parliament that the required 75 per cent of nations did not support the sanctuary, and therefore this protection was not afforded to the whales of the South Pacific. As a member from Tasmania, which has a long history of whaling and now whale watching, I am very pleased to have this opportunity to speak.

speech.para: The International Whaling Commission was established in 1946 to monitor the whaling industry and conserve whale populations. In 1985-86 a global moratorium was placed on commercial whaling to protect whale populations which had been severely depleted by whaling. One thousand whales are still killed each year under exceptions which are granted for scientific research and whaling by indigenous communities. Unfortunately, Australia's history of whaling has led to a severe depletion in whale stocks. Species like the southern right whale were hunted almost to extinction.

Commercial whaling began in Australia in the early 1800s, with the blubber from these magnificent creatures used for products such as lamp oil, candles and soaps. Whale and seal blubber were among Australia's biggest exports by the 1850s. Whale quotas were not introduced until the 1950s, when much of the damage had already been done to our whale populations. It was not until the late 1970s that we finally banned whaling in Australian waters. Several years ago, Russia admitted that it had been secretly whaling for years, which is thought to explain the very slow recovery rate of whale numbers in Australian waters in the 1980s. Populations of humpback whales have not recovered in New Zealand waters, and it is expected that they may never do so. Is it not now time to give these creatures, who have benefited our country so richly, a safe haven in which to live and rebuild their species in peace?

At this year's International Whaling Commission meeting in July, delegates from 43 countries met to consider all sides of the arguments for creating whale sanctuaries and to review the global moratorium. Australia and New Zealand were among the nations which were pushing the attempt to establish a South Pacific whale sanctuary. Very sadly, this motion was defeated, but not without controversy. There have been reports of pro-whaling countries buying the votes of countries that have no whaling industry, with the promise of aid. At last year's IWC meeting the environment minister of Dominica resigned saying that he was disgusted after his government's representative voted against the South Pacific whale sanctuary. He said:

quote.para: I am alarmed that the Japanese seem to be using the promise of aid to manipulate voting at the IWC ... there is absolutely no reason for us to be held ransom by Japan in return for promises of aid.

speech.para: After this year's meeting even stronger condemnation came from Mick McIntyre, director of the Asia-Pacific office of the International Fund for Animal Welfare. He said:

quote.para: This wasn't a vote ... this was an Auction and Japan was the highest bidder ... It is also a slap in the face for the small island nations of the south pacific, most of whom are not represented here ... It is inexplicable that the small island states of the eastern Carribean, who work so closely with south pacific nations on other issues, should turn their backs on their sister island states of the south pacific.

speech.para: This month New Zealand Prime Minister Helen Clark attended the 16-nation Pacific Island Forum on the island nation of Nauru, where the failure of the proposed sanctuary was discussed. Ms Clark said:

quote.para: There was complete unanimity on the recommendation that we should pursue the whaling free sanctuary.

speech.para: It is not merely a moral or emotional argument that says this sanctuary is a good idea; it actually makes rather excellent economic sense. The economically disadvantaged states of the South Pacific rely heavily on tourism for their survival and for their livelihood. Worldwide, whale watching is worth more than $1 billion annually. Compare that lifelong, sustainable figure with the profit from whaling in Japan and Norway at just $50 million. Logic as well as emotion tell me that we must vigorously pursue this project.

In Australia, tourist meccas such as Hervey Bay place a value of $100,000 for each humpback whale that visits their waters. Another benefit of this sanctuary would be its value to scientific research. Whales live for many years and information needed for their long-term global management, such as the ecosystems in which they live, is still needed. A recent scientific discovery was made two kilometres off the Victorian coast at Warrnambool where a blue whale feeding ground was found. It is caused by the cold water current that attracts the krill and plankton that blue whales scoop up by the tonne. This has come as quite a surprise to the scientific world and leads one to wonder what else we could discover about the many species of whales which pass through our waters.

I am very pleased that Australia is finally taking a lead on a global environmental issue. I call on Minister Hill to continue his push to establish this vital sanctuary and continue down the road of redressing past wrongs. I congratulate those members who have taken the time to raise and speak on this issue today. I hope that we will get some progress in the establishment of such a sanctuary. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: (Hon. D.G.H. Adams)âOrder! The time allotted for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting.

motion.para: That grievances be noted.

talk.start.para: âI rise in the grievance debate to place on record the total incompetence this government has shown in managing the Natural Heritage Trust, and the complete lack of adequate funding that Labor electorates, such as mine, have received from the trust. Recently, I asked the Minister for the Environment and Heritage a question on notice, to list all of the approved project applications and their full costings for the Sydney electorates of Prospect, Chifley, Fowler, Reid, Blaxland, Macarthur, Werriwa, Parramatta, Lindsay, Greenway, Mitchell and Macquarie. The minister has recently supplied me with the answer, which I will convey to the House later in this debate.

speech.para: However, first I would like to bring to the House's attention the urgent need for my electorate to receive funding from the Natural Heritage Trust, and from other sources of federal funding, for very badly needed environmental projects. Within the local government area of Fairfieldâa city which has a population of some 200,000 and which, of course, makes up nearly two-thirds of my electorateâis a vital network of creeks, which are subcatchments of the Georges River and the Botany Bay catchments. These two catchments contain the five major urban creeks: Prospect Creek, Orphan School Creek, Clear Paddock Creek, Green Valley Creek and Cabramatta Creek. One of the largest of these creeks, Prospect Creek, runs right through my electorate and joins Orphan School Creek, which is also within my electorate.

Since the 1960s, this valuable creek system has suffered from stormwater pollution, unsewered residential development and industrial pollution. The natural beauty of these creeks has been spoiled by development and continual flooding over many years, which has turned what was once a recreational, natural landscape that families could enjoy into a place which has needed urgent upgrading and, as yet, has not received funding from the federal government. Fairfield council have had to fund their entire five creeks strategy from local government rates. Earlier this year, I raised this issue of the five creeks in an appropriation debate with the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, Dr Sharman Stone. These were her remarks in reply:

quote.para: Weâ

speech.para: meaning the governmentâ

quote.para: have been very conscious of urban environments and the degradation of water supplies, air quality and noise abatement. There is a whole range of urban environmental issues that the Natural Heritage Trust specifically identified and addressed.

speech.para: I say to the parliamentary secretary that the minister's reply to my question on notice has clearly shown where the Natural Heritage Trust has specified and addressed the urban environmental issues, and that is in the marginal Liberal held electorates. Here are the figures to prove that statement. I asked the minister for the total sum of Commonwealth funding to projects which were successful in receiving Natural Heritage Trust funding in 1999-2000 and 2000-01 for the electorates which neighbour or which are close to my electorate. I would like to read those figures to the House. My electorate of Prospect received nothing in 1999-2000 but received a small amount of $17,500 for a wetlands strategy in Abbotsbury. I would like to go through the other Labor-held seats: Chifley received $15,000 in 1999-2000 and nothing in 2000-01; Fowler, $13,770 in 1999-2000 and $24,225 in 2001; Greenway, $4,408 in 1999-2000 and then nothing in 2000-01; Reid, $42,627 combined in the two years; and Blaxland, $18,866 in 1999-2000 and $11,576 in 2000-01. I am sure most members will agree that these funding measures range from a pittance to something that was probably just adequate for minor natural heritage projects.

But now I would like to go through the coalition seatsâand remember that the above electorates share common boundaries with all these seats. The seat of Lindsay received $83,713 over the two years; Mitchell received $128,305 over the two years; Macquarie received $380,423 over the two years; Macarthur received $366,548 over the two years; and Parramatta, one of the most marginal government-held seats in Sydney, received a total of $636,419 over the two years. I repeat for the members in the House: Parramatta received the total sum of $636,419 in Natural Heritage Trust funding over two years. Compare this with the funding in my electorate, which came to a total of $17,500. By the way, for the information of those in the House, Parramatta and my electorate of Prospect share a common road; yet this is the type of funding we received.

The list provided by the minister shows that large amounts of this Commonwealth money have funded in Parramatta local government projects which are very similar to the projects which Fairfield City Council is proposing through its five creeks program. I believe that this shows the utter arrogance of the government in picking and choosing which electorates are worthy of receiving Natural Heritage Trust funding and which are not. The money that has funded the Natural Heritage Trust Fund came from the government's decision to partially sell off Telstra, which was a publicly owned and nationally important telecommunications carrier. The proceeds of the sale should benefit all parts of Australia, including urban areas and electorates like mine and neighbouring Labor electorates. When I raised the matter of the Fairfield Council's five creek program in that appropriation debate, the parliamentary secretary said:

quote.para: Please come and knock on my door as well because, as parliamentary secretary, I am able to help people just like your five-creek plan group on very many occasions.

speech.para: Later, she said:

quote.para: Again, it just might be that the councils in the member for Prospect's electorate are not fully aware of those opportunitiesâ

speech.para: Not much! I say now to the parliamentary secretary and to the minister: the council in my electorate have knocked on your door. They have put in their submissions, which I sent to your office personally with a letter dated 3 August 2001, and they are still awaiting a response. I can only hope that it will be a positive one.

I would also like to mention the lack of full explanation of some of the funding arrangements mentioned in the minister's reply, especially in regard to the projects for which no application for funding was received, and for what the minister calls `education and awareness programs'. When the minister claims that $274.7 million of Commonwealth funds has been appropriated to the Natural Heritage Trust, while my electorate has received only a pittance of this money, it is a matter of accountability that these projects be explained in more detail. Also needed to be asked is: how much of the money has been used for the promotion and advertisement of the Natural Heritage Trust that has saturated Australian newspapers and television, while the marginal electorates receive the most amount of money and electorates like mine do not?

Questions also need to be asked of this government as to why the electorate of Parramattaâan urban electorate which, as I explained, is very similar to mineâreceived $636,419 while mine received $17,400; and also why neighbouring electorates, such as Chifley, received only $15,000 over two years. The minister cannot possibly claim that more applications were received from areas within Parramatta or Lindsay and that that was the reason for the significant difference in the figures between the electorates.

According to the minister's answer, there were 8,014 applications received in 1999-2000, while there were only 3,915 approved. In 2000-01 there were 7,084 applications received, and 3,416 were approved. It would be very interesting to learn the electorates from which unsuccessful applications came. However, as the minister told me in his answer to my question, there are no location based data for the unsuccessful applications. How interesting is that! The government have collected information on submissions and funding, but we have no location based data for the unsuccessful applications.

It is vital for urban areas and electorates such as mine to receive federal funding from the Natural Heritage Trust. Important environmental projects which will have several benefits for the people in my electorate and for Sydney's urban waterway system need to be completed. The Natural Heritage Trust was funded, I repeat, by the sale of Telstra, a public asset, so this government has the responsibility to use the money to benefit all Australians, not just those who live in the marginal government held electorates.

It is also very interesting when one looks at some of the programsâand I took myself physically around some of the areas to see what is being achieved by the natural heritage fundingâand sees the similarity in programs that have already been applied from those surrounding neighbourhood electorates. Again, I would understand and appreciate if the electorates that I am talking about were in different statesâif I was taking examples from the state of New South Wales, the state of Victoria and the state of Western Australia. I am talking about a collection of federal electorates that encompass what I say is Sydney's greater west. I am talking about electorates that go cheek by jowl with a neighbouring electorate; they have the same environmental concerns and problems. In fact, some of the creek systems and the waterway systems run from one electorate to another. We do not have a border which stops the water coming out of one electorate and going into the other, yet we do have a border when we have the allocation of public funds which have resulted from the sale of a public asset such as Telstra being distributed in electorates in a most uneven and underhanded way.

I believe that the minister and the parliamentary secretary have to look more closely at what has happened here. I do not believe that it is an issue that is going to be kept quiet, because the councils in the electorates now know how the distribution of funds has been made over these last two years, why it has been made and to whom it has been made. I believe what has to be questioned and continue to be questioned by us in opposition, and particularly by the government members who make up this parliament, is: why are funding allocations being done in a way that shows such a gross inadequacy between one area and the area next door which is on a very similar plane?

I believe that there are a lot more answers that the minister needs to provide to the question on notice. I do not think it is something that is going to go away. More particularly, we need to have a far greater explanation than just, `We don't have the locations of those applications that have missed out.' Perhaps the ones that missed out have come from areas that I have mentioned that received no funding or very little funding; maybe they did, maybe they didn't. But when you do not have an answer to that question, it leaves the question outstanding: where has the money gone? (Time expired)

talker.name: Worth, Trish, MP
Ms WORTH
