talk.start.para: âMany of us become so busy in this life that we do not often enough take the time to reflect on what we can be doing in the future and what has already been achieved. I note on some reflection that this is the 20th anniversary of the political exchange program, and I know that members from all political parties have benefited from this program. I visited the United States for the Bush-Dukakis election in 1988, and one slogan that stuck in my mind from that timeâalthough I also have many happy memories and gained some very good experienceâwas that George Bush Sr wanted to see a `kinder, gentler America'. One of the things that I thought about when I came here over eight years ago was that I wanted to see a kinder, gentler Australia and I wanted to see more people benefit from what government can do and from what we should all be setting out to achieve. I guess I could speak for a lot longer than 10 minutes on this, but I would just like to mention some things that I am proud this government has achieved and that I know my fellow Australians have benefited from.

speech.para: Along the `kinder, gentler Australia' line, we have introduced gun control and we have paid back the dreadful debt that this government inherited, which we must do for our children's sake. I know it is not an original line, but it has been said that debt for the next generation is a form of child abuse. I note too from reading the Sydney Morning Herald on the weekend that the National Centre for Social and Economic Modelling at the University of Canberra has done some work which has shown the benefits that have resulted for Australian families since the Howard government came to power in 1996.

I particularly note that 25 per cent of the families in my electorate are sole parent families and they have benefited significantly from this government. But every family studiedâfrom the affluent, dual income couples to the most struggling sole parentsâ has more disposable income now thanks to the Howard government. Before the GST tax changes and compensation, a sole parent on welfare with two children had disposable income of $312 a week; after those changes, their new disposable income is $371âan increase of $59 or 19 per cent. Single income families on average weekly earnings with two children have also benefited. Prior disposable income was $565 a week, and the current disposable income is $653âan increase of $88 a week or 16 per cent.

A few weeks ago, the TV program A Current Affair had a feature on some time that I spent with Chris and Des Morgan and their family when I agreed to live on their budget for a week. I enjoyed the challenge, as I was reminded of how careful I had had to be when my own children were young and I was the only income earner. I much admired the way Chris and Des managed with their three beautiful children. The exercise brought home to me the benefits of this government's policyâDes earns approximately $29,500 per year, and the family receives family allowances of $11,300 per year and is entitled to a health care card.

It is important that we continue to help those not so well off in our community. To do so, we need a good, strong government in this country, a government capable of making tough decisions so that not only we but also our children and grandchildren are better off. Steven Gianni, director of social action research at the Brotherhood of St Laurence, was quoted in the Sydney Morning Herald as saying:

quote.para: The changes that have occurred have really benefited families. The Government should be congratulated.

speech.para: The Howard government has been good for families. We have given families, whether they be one- or two-parent households, a legitimate and feasible choice of both parents continuing to workâif there are two parentsâor, if they wish instead, of one parent remaining at home. Unlike the previous Labor government, which allowed support for single income families to drop by four per cent in real terms, we are looking after these families.

I turn now to the issue of health, and I note that the Leader of the Opposition and some members opposite have wanted us to talk about health and educationâit is as though we should be shivering in our boots and not wanting to discuss these subjects. I say, `Let's bring it on. Let's talk about health and education as long as you like, because we have done a great job in both areas.' The Leader of the Opposition was quoted in an article by Paul Kelly in the Weekend Australian as saying:

quote.para: We say, we are responsible.

speech.para: that is, for the health of all Australiansâ

quote.para: We, the national governmentâ

speech.para: and he is obviously hoping to be thereâ

quote.para: should take these matters on. That's what this dispute, fundamentally, is about.

speech.para: I think this would be rather surprising to state governments, who like to think that they have the control of schools and public hospitals. I note that Paul Kelly did add:

quote.para: This has a Whitlamite ring. Where, but where, is the money?

speech.para: He also went on to say:

quote.para: Kim fouled up. He should never have introduced his daughter into the health debate. It was a serious mistake, and it was compounded by more blunders involving media briefings and Beazley exaggerations of his daughter's plight. Beazley made a mistake in political judgment ...

speech.para: I note that the Leader of the Opposition has not as yet said sorry.

Further on health, Australians will not forget that it was the Labor Party that left only half our children immunised in 1996, it was Labor that allowed an exodus of doctors from rural areas, and it was the Labor Party that failed to improve the health of the Aboriginal population. Australians will also remember how the Labor Party placed Medicare and our public hospital system under great strain because it ignored the private health system for 13 years. In contrast to Labor's poor record on health, the coalition has strengthened Medicare, and the Howard government will be spending a record $29 billion on health this year. We have committed an extra $750 million to Medicare to allow doctors to better treat patients with asthma, diabetes and mental illness and to improve the rates of cervical cancer screening amongst women, particularly those living in rural Australia. The coalition has also provided the states and territories this year with a record $6.7 billion for their public hospital systems.

It almost seems that the opposition needs to be reminded that the health of the citizens of this country is not just about public hospitals. Public hospitals and their accident and emergency systems are enormously importantâand I have to say that I have personally benefited from them, as I know many others have as well. But there are issues like asthma, which affects two million Australians, including one in four primary school children, one in seven teenagers and one in 10 adults, and around 700 people a year die from asthma. We now have a special project running and an asthma-friendly schools programâand I was pleased to launch the South Australian leg of that only a few months ago.

There is now a national diabetes strategy, which was launched in 1999. We are doing more now for mental health than has ever been done before. As we heard the Minister for Health and Aged Care say in question time today, we are leading the world in this area. We have a strategy that covers consumer rights, linking mental health services with other sectors, the mental health work force, legislation, research and evaluation, standards, monitoring and accountability.

The National Depression Initiative, Beyond Blue, forms the focal point for our efforts to address the health burden of depression on the Australian communityâand depression is a leading cause of illness and disability in Australia. We have had a National Suicide Prevention Strategy. We know that most people use their GP as the first point of entry for help with mental health issues. In recognition of this, the government has provided $120 million over four years to assist GPs to develop their skills in mental health diagnosis, care planning and treatment.

This strategy has been taken into our schools with the Mind Matters program. We have so many other things happening. The campaign to reduce smoking in Australia has resulted in Australia having the lowest level of smoking of any country in the world. We have an excellent program also for educating young people about drugs in schools so that hopefully they will have healthier and happier lifestyles. We have provided information for parents and for teachers about bullying in schools, which of course can be a serious issue for young people. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âThere are two issues I wish to raise in the grievance debate. One is the endless saga of the Child Support Scheme; the other relates to the timely exposure in the Weekend Australian about border control, which the Howard government is failing miserably to police.

speech.para: I and many other members from both sides have been critical of the Child Support Scheme and its administration for many years. We have all arguedâbecause we see these cases every day in our officesâthat the scheme, its administration and the assessments made need major reform. We start from the principle that parents are responsible for raising their children; they are responsible for the emotional and financial wellbeing of their children. This responsibility continues, especially when the parents separate or divorce. I must say that, in the vast majority of cases, both custodial and non-custodial parents do recognise this responsibility. The non-custodial parents that I have encountered since the Child Support Scheme was introduced over a decade ago do recognise their continuing responsibility to their children. What they argue for is that there be some fairness in the payment of child support. They argue for the assessment to be based on net rather than gross income. It is unreasonable, in my view, that the assessment of the payee is based on gross income. No-one in Australia gets what is stated on his or her tax return at the end of the financial year.

In the last few years, some of the arguments we have had in this place about reforming child support have led to the implementation of amendments to the legislation. I am on the record as supporting these changes that I feel have made child support administration fairer. I particularly support the reforms to take into account the second family of payees. Why should the second family of a payee come off second best to the first family? But there are flaws in the government's reform in this case that have been brought to my attention by a particular constitutent's case. In a letter to me, dated 13 August, my constituent said:

quote.para: This legislation will allow me to be able to earn extra income, through overtime, to benefit my daughter from my second marriage ...

speech.para: However, the thrust of the new reforms requires the circumstances of the second family to be known by the provision of the financial details of the second wife to the Child Support Agency. In other words, the CSA needs to know the financial details of the second wife to find out whether it is necessary for the payee to work overtime to support the child from the second marriage or whether the second wife can fully support the child herself. My constituent objects to his second wife being taken through this process, and I must say that I tend to agree. He also has the added complication of funding ongoing legal costs to obtain contact with the children from his first marriage.

This is a problem with the Child Support Scheme. Every time we fix up one area, another anomaly appears. It is like the dam wall: every hole we plug just creates extra pressure elsewhere until it, too, breaks. I have said before in this place that the Child Support Scheme needs some major reform. The more I see these types of cases coming through my office, the more I become convinced that this legislation should be set aside and that we need to start again. We passed legislation in this place, which came into effect on 30 June, to give some potential to second families to have some financial security. Instead, the situation is now more complicated. I do not suggest that making the Child Support Scheme fairer will be easy; we already have some experience in this attempt. But we have an obligation to try. I do not believe that we can keep amending legislation in the faint hope we get it right. The current legislation does not work; it is not fair; it is frustratingly complicated. We are further adding to the emotional battle that too many separating and divorced parents are involved in. And it is all at the expense of the children that the legislation was supposed to act for. Throw out this law and let us start again: that has been my constant call. We can design a new system; we can make it benefit children; we can take away the use of these kids as pawns in a battle between warring parents. They are owed a system that works.

The second issue I raise is the expose in the Weekend Australian of our borders. Frankly, they are open all hours because the Howard government has failed miserably to ensure their protection. Throughout the two terms of this government, the exposure of Australia's borders has been a constant feature of attention. We have the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs brutally and ruthlessly attacking asylum seekers coming to Australia, locking them up and demonising them. But our borders are exposed and vulnerable. Illegal immigrants, trade in wildlife, illicit drugs and other items are brought to Australia every single hour of the day without detection.

Today in the Australian, on page 4, is the headline `Boatpeople second to airport illegals'. The government has been warned about these problems since 1996 when it took the axe to law enforcement agencies in Australia by security intelligence. The report over the weekend made the startling claim that just three in every 10,000 shipping containers are physically inspected by Customs. The Minister for Justice and Customs said today that Australian ports would grind to a halt if we were forced to inspect every shipping container.

I have a busy port in my electorate, Port Kembla, which has over 500 ship visits each and every year. It is one of Australia's busiest port facilities on the east coast of Australia and, with the activities of the Port Kembla Port Corporation to attract more use of the port, it will become even busier in the years ahead. We used to have in the Illawarra something like 16 Customs officials based at the waterfront in Port Kembla, just a step away from the wharf. There are now just four or five officials there. The Port Kembla Customs officials, whom I have had much to do with and greatly respect for their diligence and professionalism in difficult circumstances, are no longer based at Port Kembla. They are now located in the Wollongong central business district, in Ellen Street, Wollongong. They work office hours: 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. They are at least 15 minutes away from the port facilities. But, more importantly, they service a hugely diverse geographic area from Helensburgh in the north of the Illawarra to the Victorian border in the south. I am confident that Port Kembla is a wide-open port. We are just over an hour from the Sydney central business district and centres like Liverpool, Campbelltown and Cabramatta.

I have invited each and every one of the five Customs ministers in this government since 1996 to visit Port Kembla with me. None has ever taken up my invitation. I remember vividly my last conversation with a Customs minister. It was former Customs Minister Truss, after a dinner in the Great Hall. We crossed paths and we talked about him visiting Port Kembla. I said that I was keen for him to come and I promised I would not make his visit political. I wanted him to visit, inspect Port Kembla, talk to Customs officials, officials from the port corporation, the MUA, business and other groups. He never came. In fact, he flew over my electorate on the way down to see the member for Gilmore a couple of years ago. He did not dare set foot in Throsby but flew right over it.

We have had the saga of the cameras at Port Kembla, and I have raised it many times in this place. The government told me, in an answer to a question on notice, that cameras would be put into Port Kembla to increase surveillance. As I recall, it was the then Customs Minister Vanstone who issued a media release late one night saying that Port Kembla would have the good fortune to have nine surveillance cameras. At the time I welcomed the announcement, except that I pointed out that I had been promised such cameras by Minister Truss some months earlier. In fact, after much fanfare I made some routine inquiries of some people at the port about the cameras, only to discover they were damaged and had been boxed up and taken back to Sydney. If it were not so serious, it would have been a joke. I am now told that the cameras are at the port and are operating, but they are monitored in Melbourne. Can you believe it? What a farce!

Imagine it: we will have an official in the middle of the night, in Melbourne, detect some suspect incident on the ship, someone coming down the gangway in Port Kembla or people rushing up and down the gangplank carrying all sorts of things off the ship. He or she from Melbourne will ring the Customs office in Ellen Street, Wollongong, and get an answering machine because the people work there from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. The next attempt will be the much vaunted flying squad rushing down the F6 from Sydney. As the flying squad speeds down the F6 trying to head off the so-called `importers' at Port Kembla, the importers will be speeding their way up the F6 to disappear into metropolitan Sydney. It is a joke. They will wave to each other as they pass in the night.

The fact is that Australia's ports, airports and borders are wide open. This government's cutbacks to law enforcement, Customs and the Federal Police have left our borders vulnerable and exposed. Labor have revealed our policy responses and we will establish an Australian coastguard. The government last week criticised this, but they have been penny wise and pound foolish. In fact, they have disregarded the fact that this country has a huge coastline and that every available resource, particularly of personnel, must be directed to ensure territorial integrity. Smugglers from all over the world know that Australia is an easy touch to get into and get things out of because there is little or no effective vigilance at our ports. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âGold Coast city, Australia's sixth largest city, is the fastest-growing region in Australia. Part of its attraction is the surf and sand, the climate and the range of living styles available in the city, from high-rise on the coastal strip to rural residential in the hinterland. Queensland is also attracting increasing numbers of people captivated by its mellow lifestyle. It is an attractive place to live and is considered a good place to raise children in a safe and protected environment.

speech.para: Queensland is also a state with chronic system failureâthe failure of the Department of Families, to protect abused children due to massive underfunding. The seriousness of the problem is seen in our child abuse numbers, with Queensland having the highest rate per capita of substantiated child abuse cases, followed by the Northern Territory, Victoria and South Australia. We also spend less on child protection than any other state.

The 1999 Commission of Inquiry into the Abuse of Children in Queensland Institutionsâthe Forde inquiryâfound that Queensland spent the lowest percentage on child protection relative to all other states and territories. The Forde inquiry recommended the families department budget be boosted by $103 million to meet the national average per capita welfare spending for children and to maintain the increase in line with the national average. Also, a report to state parliament estimates that the Queensland families department needs an extra $171 million to function properly. But we have a state government that has chosen to ignore the findings of the Forde inquiry and the report to its parliament by allocating very little extra fundingâfor example, $25 million in recurrent funding in the last two years of its last term, an additional $20 million in the next two years and over $5.2 million in the last budget. This allocation is contemptible and grossly inadequate to protect abused children. The department needs far more funding to operate in a satisfactory manner and to address its unrealistic workloads and the inadequate support and training given to workers expected to carry out work far beyond their experience.

The effect of this lack of funding is felt directly on the Gold Coast, where we have no free, state funded counselling service focusing on young children. This is not only negligence on the government's part but incredible considering that we have some of the worst child abuse in numbers in the country. I have had numerous approaches by representatives of the Abused Child Trust, asking what can be done to get the state government to face up to its obligations and provide a full-time service.

The Abused Child Trust runs Contact House on the Gold Coast, which is staffed two days a week by a psychologist. Funding for this service does comes not from the Beattie government but from Pacific Fair Shopping Centre and the Broadwater-Southport Rotary Club. An urgent need has been identified for the provision of a full-time service on the Gold Coast so that counselling can be given to abused children. The work the trust does is imperative. The analogy used is that of the ambulance at the bottom of the cliff: it is there to pick up the pieces and put them together again.

I call on the Beattie government to urgently direct funds into the establishment of a contact house on the Gold Coast so as to provide the level of support that abused children need and to help break the cycle of abuse.

It appears that abuse is a learned behaviour, which, without intervention, is likely to continue from generation to generation. The consequences of abuse are serious and pervasive. Relationships may be dysfunctional. Low esteem and self-worth, compounded by lack of education, can develop into mental health problems that further limit the victims' capacity to achieve human and economic potential, and they are more likely to have further adverse life experiences. I will read some extracts from the Forde inquiry on the effect of physical, sexual and mental abuse:

quote.para: There are seven main outcomes of physical abuse: aggressive and violent behaviour, non-violent criminal behaviour, substance abuse, self-injurious and suicidal behaviour, emotional problems, interpersonal problems, and academic and vocational difficulties.

There is now little doubt about the relationship between childhood physical abuse and emotional and psychological problems in later life. These problems include anxiety, depression, hostility, paranoid thoughts, psychosis and disassociation disorders.
Adolescents and adults who exhibit violent behaviours have often been abused as children.

speech.para: On another form of abuse the inquiry report said:

quote.para: Child sexual abuse is now widely regarded as causing mental health problems in adult life. Specifically, child sexual abuse has an impact on social, sexual and interpersonal functioning, and affects the child's developing capacities for trust, intimacy, mastery of their world.
A history of child sexual abuse is reported to be associated with insecure and disorganised attachments, poor self-esteem and increased rates of relationship breakdown.

speech.para: Finally, on emotional abuse, the inquiry report says:

quote.para: There is a developing agreement that emotional maltreatment is a fundamental cause of negative developmental outcomes for children.
For those children exposed to psychological abuse over some years, the resulting inability to develop good relationships with others creates a vulnerability to further abuse.

speech.para: It also says that adults who suffer abuse as children have experienced profoundly disturbed lives as a result of that abuse and they are likely to have more negative life experiences than other people.

The chronic underfunding of the Department of Families is subjecting these underprivileged people to a further abuse, that of systems abuse. The system is replicating the abuse and neglect patterns attributed to its client group. Ultimately, the effectiveness of leaders as leaders will be tested by the achievement of purpose in the form of real and intended social change. I call on the Beattie government to show leadership, bring about social change and not continue to ignore and fail Queensland's abused children. There are now seven Labor state members on the Gold Coast. My challenge to them is to lobby their government to provide funding to ensure that abused children on the Gold Coast have adequate full-time services to address their very serious needs.

para.inline: Sitting suspended from 6.29 p.m. to 8.00 p.m.

talk.start.para: âMy grievance today is about health and health funding. It does not matter where I turn in my electorate, health is the number one issue, and that is because the government have cut the funding of public hospital facilities. The whole issue seems to revolve around that. If Tasmania, at the very least, could access some of the $3.5 million that has been allocated to be spent on government advertising in Tasmania since July this year and reallocate it to health, we might be able to do something about our waiting lists. I have been watching the advertisements that the government have been running. Some of them talk about programs that were introduced ages ago. Why the government should want to bother trying to get people to sign up for them now really beats me.

speech.para: Some $500,000 a month is being used on government advertising in Tasmania; that is, Tasmania's share of the $20 million a month is being squandered nationwide. I am sure that the advertising agencies and the media are very happy with that program, but it is doing nothing to help those who really need the services that could be put in place with that sort of money. The government's trumpet has been blown long enough and the tune has become very tedious. The community wants funding for services. The member for Bass, Michelle O'Byrne, has pointed out that $500,000 would fund 21 acute care beds and 24 surgical beds for a month. She is right. Those are the sorts of things that the government should be fundingânot propping up the advertising budget of a couple of media outlets.

I will tell the House about some things that are happening in my electorate of Lyons. I had a recent case of a man from Queenstown who was waiting for an operation. His operation had been scheduled and he was advised to go to Hobart. He had to make arrangements for someone to look after his house and pets, organise his affairs while he was away, and find a HACC car to take him to Hobart, which is a 3Â½-hour trip one way. When he arrived, he was prepared and then he waited. After a few hours he was told that surgery for the day had been cancelled and that he would have to go home. They could not give him another date, as they were behind with surgery and there were no beds available for him to wait in, so he had to trail all the way back to Queenstown, unravel all his arrangements, and wait for the next time. Maybe his operation was not done because his life was not threatened, but he was in pain and he had been for some time. His time had come up and he spent quite a lot of money sorting out his affairs and arranging his transport to and from Hobart, and still he had to wait. Another case involved a man who was waiting to have a knee investigation carried out. Once again, he was in pain and considerable discomfort. He could not walk easily and he had been waiting for 18 months for the investigation to see what could be done. He still has not been seen to, although they say that he is now on top of the list. I dread to think how long he will have to wait after that process has been carried out.

We have similar problems with dental care. I have heard some horrible stories about pensioners waiting for years to have their teeth fixed. One woman who rang me recently had been waiting for two years to have her dental plate fixed, and in all that time she had been unable to eat properly. I finally persuaded the clinic that the case was urgent. She was not alone in having difficulties in having her teeth attended to. Ever since pensioners have been unable to get the dental health care they had under the previous Labor government, we have had calls every week about sad, disturbing cases of people being left out of the health care loop. I cannot be told that it is the responsibility of the state government; it is everybody's responsibility that there is proper health care for all Australians, whether or not they have money. The federal government is not allocating sufficient funds to cover services, particularly services in the country.

There are endless stories of health disasters and of people having to wait an unreasonable time just to get the preliminaries done. Another tooth story had a patient waiting in huge pain for two months. Finally, he was told to go up to Launceston for assistance, on a sit and wait basis. That means that one does not necessarily get an appointment. Fortunately, on that occasion he was looked at and the tooth was packed, but not fixed. He had to wait another few weeks to have the tooth pulled, and still he had a problem with pain. It is not a question of health in Australia; it is a question of avoiding sickness by all possible means, as it is quite possible that you will have to wait in misery to get help.

Then there is the question of finding and keeping GPs in Tasmania. As I mentioned the previous time I spoke on health, Tasmania has a problem with doctors' practices in country areas. One area has been reclassified as a status 1 metropolitan practice because of the enormous difficulties in recruiting doctors in rural practices. The government keeps saying through the bureaucrats that there are enough doctors to meet population needs and that local doctors should enter medical practice in areas where population needs for medical care are not met. However, unless there are some incentives and a good backup system for doctors, they are not going to move to the country. One doctor on the east coast literally has to close his practice to have some time off. Others close their books to new patients, leaving them to travel hundreds of kilometres to gain assistance. I suggest that the whole state should be deemed rural, as we have small isolated populations that cannot be called metropolitan by any stretch of the imagination. I contend that anything outside the immediate boundaries of the Hobart and Launceston regions should be rural. Areas such as New Norfolk and Sorell have great difficulties because they are not attached to a major medical facility or hospital. They cannot get relief staff easily, and any temporary help through the OTD scheme is being allowed only for a temporary period. We cannot expect doctors to come here for a year and then be replaced. It often takes six to 12 months to find one, anyway.

I know that many rural Tasmanian doctors go to the government for help, but help is not forthcoming. Their arguments are cogent and they do not want anything more at this stage than for those areas to continue to be recognised as rural areas, or RRMA 5 areas, and the half-and-half status proposed in some of the cases just does not work. Somehow, this important issue has to be dealt with. This is having an impact on other health services and, once again, it seems that people in the country having to travel to cities for assistance are consigned to long and intolerable waiting lists. We have heard what it is like in Western Australia, where they probably have similar problems for their country clients.

I am very aggrieved by this government's inability to see the problems in the rural areas. But maybe they do see and they do not care about them, because it is only in certain regions which have small numbers of voters that they do not seem to care. Is this the cynical exercise again? Spend heaps of money on advertising because lots of people are likely to see it, but do not bother to fix a problem which will affect only a few thousand. This is where this government continually goes wrong.

I keep asking about the situation of the doctors in New Norfolk and I still have not received from the Minister for Health and Aged Care a reply or even a letter acknowledging my letter. That dates back about six months. That is an appalling state of affairs. We need more money to be spent on health care, aged care and disability services, and we then need to consider the needs of our youth, tooâeducation, child care, children's health, and one could go on. It is time for a change in government, and I think that will happen very soon.

talker.name: Nelson, Dr Brendan, MP
Dr NELSON
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: âFor almost six years I have had the privilege to represent the electorate of Bradfield, which is on what is known as the Upper North Shore of Sydney. Following the redistribution, it extends from North Willoughby up the Pacific Highway through Chatswood, north to Wahroonga, across to West Pymble on the western side and to Castle Cove on the eastern side. I wish to speak about some issues which, whilst in one sense specific to my own electorate, affect almost every Australian to varying degrees.

speech.para: Most of us harbour deep reservations about the sort of society and the kind of world that we will leave our children. Although we are extremely concerned about our day-to-day endeavours and the problems we face in life, I think most of us are particularly concerned about the extent to which we nurture the idealism of our children and we protect their vulnerable transition to adulthood. Over the last two years, I have noticed in my electorate a deteriorating situation in relation to the behaviour of a small minority of young people, some of whom come from my area and some of whom do not, in respect of congregation in and around train stations and platforms, the dealing of drugs, assaults by some young people on others, and the presence of alleged gangs. A couple of days ago, I said to one of my constituents who seemed to think that this was not an issue about which we ought to be concerned, `You need to understand that two levels of crime are being committed in our society. The first, which we do not expect but which we come to accept as part of human endeavour, is the sorts of crimes that are perpetrated against adults. The second is a world of increasing fear for young people who live in Sydney and who move in and around Sydney, particularly late in the afternoon and early in the evening. That is a world to which we adults seem oblivious.'
One of my constituents sent me a letter which in part read:

quote.para: Dr Nelson, my son was seriously assaulted right outside his school by an ethnic gang. He spent several days in hospital. I was horrified to learn he had been the go-between in a drug deal but had then refused to cooperate. The police have been wonderful, but do parents have any idea what's going on?

speech.para: This is just one of around 30 frightening and, sadly, typical comments that have been made to me since I have spent the last year peeling an onion of misbehaviour by some people in and around train stations on the North Shore.

Four months ago, I surveyed young people in my area in an attempt to find out directly from them what their concerns were. Eleven hundred and seventy-nine young people responded to the survey and 79 per cent said that they were aware of assaults, 200 had been direct witnesses and a staggering 69 per cent confirmed the dealing of illicit drugs in and around train station precincts. I suppose like most parents, I asked myself why this might be the case. Some of the most important research that has been done in Australia in relation to the concerns of young people has been done by the Victorian Centre for Adolescent Health. Last year, it published its survey of 9,000 students in years 7, 9 and 11, and it found extensive evidence of a direct correlation of antisocial behaviours and substance abuse such as under-age drinking, smoking, using cannabis, violence against others and self-harm. The three worst risk factors identified by young people were poor family management and disciplineâfor example, allowing truancy and under-age drinking, an atmosphere of constant family infighting and the ready availability of drugs. In contrast, young people saw as protective of them opportunities for positive community involvement, such as sport and youth groups, rewards from parents for good behaviour and the belief, for want of a better expression, in moral valuesâin a sense, living in a society that defines in some real sense the difference between what is right and what is wrong.

Following the survey of the young people, I then interviewed about 30 who had indicated that they would like to speak to me about these issues. One 15-year-old girl put it rather perceptively when she said, `I think the problem is that a lot of parents don't know how to be parents.' This comment was made in the context of me asking how young people got access to the amount of alcohol that they do. Contrary to popular opinion, the number one drug problem with young people is alcohol, in particular binge drinking on Thursday, Friday and Saturday nights. She said that they get it from two sources. One is that they pay someone who is 18 or older to buy the alcohol for them, but the other major source of alcohol is parents, because some parents seem to be of the view that their children are less likely to try illicit drugs if they provide them with alcohol. If we are to have any hope of instilling in our young people the confidence to be able to say no to the things which we know are not good for them, the first thing we have to do is to learn to say no to them.

One of the other things which I have responsibility for in the government in the defence area in particular is that of cadets. Not all of the things of the 20th century are necessarily those which we wish to take into the 21st, but Defence Force cadets give young people in particular a sense of belonging. They give them a sense of the need to understand the importance of working with one another, a sense of embarking upon a journey of self-development, a sense of understanding the importance of working in a team, a sense of self-esteem and, though it might seem like an old-fashioned value, a sense of self-discipline.

When I saw images on television about six weeks ago where it was reported that Aboriginal young people were rioting in Redfern and when I see images constantly on a daily basis now of problems in Cabramatta in south-western Sydney and also in Bankstown, I think that it is a pity that the New South Wales state government did not respond positively to the proposals of the Commonwealth government to let us at least pilot the integration of some Defence Force cadet units in some of those schools which are at the epicentre of the social and personal crises besetting the families and lives of some of the young people who seem to be causing more than their fair share of problems that our society is having. The Howard government has embarked on a significant range of reforms in cadets. We have increased the budget which is available for cadets by 25 per cent, so that $30 million per annum is now available for cadet activities. The first Director-General for cadets, Major-General Darryl Low Choy, has been appointed, and I recently announced the appointment of the Deputy Director-General for the cadets directorate, which will comprise 20 people in the Defence headquarters here in Canberra, and that is Ms Natalie Howson.

Apart from increasing opportunities for young people in cadets to integrate into cadet units, other opportunities include firearm education, handling and training, the computerisation of cadet units, and $840,000 worth of funding to increase opportunities for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people to involve themselves in cadet activities. I just wondered, if we put aside some of the ideological opposition that I understand some sections of the Labor movement have to Defence cadets, whether or not it would be worth trialling a cadet unit. If the Aboriginal people in Redfern or the Vietnamese community in Cabramatta were prepared to trial the introduction of a cadet unit modified to suit the specific circumstances of the young people and the families in those areas, we from the Commonwealth government and from the Department of Defence could play a role in, for example, bringing Aboriginal cadets from Redfern to the Top End of the country where a significant number of Aboriginal soldiers, both men and women, have joined Norforce and can provide some positive role models for young Aboriginal people living in our cities in the context of traditional cultural values. There is a lot of hand-wringing about the problems besetting young people, with much less emphasis focused on some of the solutions. I think Australian Defence Force cadets provide one potential opportunity for that, not to mention reminding parents of the responsibilities that we all have. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI want to speak this evening on the issue of refugees and, in particular, on the issue of the detention centre in my electorate, the Maribyrnong detention centre, and the policies that we are currently using for the continued detention of a number of people in that centre. It turns out that it is probably an appropriate day for us to be talking about this when the Prime Minister has been discussing the attitude that we as a nation are taking to turning away some several hundred people that have been picked up by a Norwegian boat off our northern coast in international waters. Whilst I do not pretend to know the detail about that issue, and I understand that there are some good reasons why we may not accept those people, it is hard as a backbencher and as a person to not worry that we might be doing something that in a couple of years time or in five, 10 or 20 years time we might think was really not the right way to treat people that have come from such difficult circumstances.

speech.para: It is in relation to this that I want to talk about the detention centre, because I think that all of us understand that there are some people in this community that do need to be detained. In fact, we do not need to have them come to Australia from other countries; we have a number of them who are home-bred and who do not comply with our laws, and we keep them in prison when they have been convicted of the criminal offences that they have committed.

The detention centre in my electorate, the Maribyrnong detention centre, which has been there for a long time, has not had much controversy surrounding it. This is because the people that have until recent times been held in the detention centre in Maribyrnongâwhich houses only about 80 people, so it is not of the scale of Woomera or Port Hedlandâmostly arrived in Australia on valid visas and by and large they are people who have been held in detention over the last 10, 15 or 20 years because they have been repeated breachers of their visas. For example, they have overstayed their visas or they have had deportation orders which they have not complied with. A number of people would be in a category where they have been convicted of criminal offences here. People may not know that people who have permanent residency, once convicted of a serious enough criminal offence, will be deported back to their country of origin.

In the community there is not a large amount of argument that those people are appropriately in detention centres and appropriately being deported. In particular, in Maribyrnong there are a large number of criminal deportees of Vietnamese background. The reason that there are a large number held at the moment is that Vietnam has refused to accept people who are being deported under these circumstances. So there are definitely people in our community who should and can be detained for good reason and deported for good reason.

It is only in more recent times that Maribyrnong has seen a mix of the people who have been held in its detention centre extend to the people who are asylum seekers, who have not committed any offence and who have arrived in this country, perhaps without the appropriate papers but seeking asylum as they are permitted to do under international law. We are now seeing coming up at the Maribyrnong detention centre a number of the issues that are being raised in other detention centres. I think the humanitarian grounds and considerations are different in circumstances of people who have arrived in that way.

I would like to talk a little bit tonight about whether we are doing the right thing with our detention policy. It is something that I understand is incredibly difficult but I do think we should try to look outside the current way of thinking. I am fearful that we might look back at the generations of people that were held in detention centres and in 20 or 30 years time will talk about them being another stolen generation. People argue that at the time the way the Aboriginal people were treated was something that was done in the best interests of those people. I know people argue about that, but it seems to me now very clear that that was a very inhumane way to treat people. I am worried that that is exactly what we will relive in another 10, 15 or 20 years with respect to the way we are treating these people.

I visited the Maribyrnong detention centre in March this year. Although I am not a member of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration, which was doing an inquiry into this matter, I went along with them as the local member and found that it was very interesting. But I was appalled to learn, for example, that there were three high school aged children held in the detention centre who were not permitted to go to school. There were a number of primary school children who were going to the local school. The staff of the detention centre took them to school of the morning and picked them up in the afternoon. But the high school aged children were not permitted to do that.

When I read what our policies are, they always include a commitment to saying that children held in detention should get educational support. It is a nonsense to say that 12-, 13- and 14-year-old boys who have been held in detention for over 18 months and not been to school are getting proper educational support. It is not as though we have a single teacher in there teaching them, either. They have one paper between them, they occasionally have access to the computer and they have some books, but otherwise they have no educational facilities at all. It seems to me the only reason they do not have accessâI have been writing and campaigning on this issue since I was thereâis because the federal and state governments cannot agree on who would actually pay for those students to be in a local state school.

The local school has said that they are happy to have them. In fact, the Maribyrnong Secondary College, which is the closest school there, is very ethnically mixed and would be entirely appropriate. They are happy to take on the challenges of educating people who are held in detention, but the state government says these people do not fit within their educational funding grounds because the people are detainees and therefore the responsibility of the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs; the department of immigration says that they do not have to pay anything extra for their education. It seems to me pretty outrageous.

Of course in the current environment every Western country is going to be a destination for asylum seekers and we cannot expect to be immune from those concerns. To date, we have been relatively protected by our physical remoteness, lack of land borders and strictly controlled visa regime. But it seems, now that access to Northern Hemisphere countries is becoming increasingly restricted and there are improvements in communication and travel, that we have seen the emergence of a profitable international people smuggling industry. We seem to be becoming a more attractive destination.

If we look at the numbers of people who are coming to this country, we need to acknowledge that introducing more domestic legislation will not deter people from arriving in this country; nor will it deter the smugglers who organise the boats. The figures over the last five years have risen dramatically in face of this government's stricter domestic legislative changes. I do not say they are causally linked, but it is clear that the steps being taken by this government are not working.

I would also like to raise the issue that, according to the figures of the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, there are nearly 59,000 people estimated to have overstayed their visas and who were illegally present in Australia at 30 June last year. The current number of boat arrivals is less than 10 per cent of that figure, yet the Howard government does not seem to be interested in taking any action on those overstaying their visas and who are thus here illegally at that time but focuses only on the asylum seekersâthose who are often in the most desperate of circumstances. When you look at the figures of how many people are accepted once they go through the application process, the rates are something like 90 per cent of those asylum seekers who arrive by boat and are detained compared to about 10 per cent of those who have arrived on a valid visa and then seek to stay here and who apply at that time.

I am very concerned because, when I visited the detention centre, assurances were made to me by both ACM and the department of immigration that as a local member of parliament I could visit at any time of my choosing. Sadly, when I have asked to visit again, both the minister and ACM have declined my request, and I am very concerned that the minister is hiding something. If these centres are well managed and humane, as the minister would have us believe, he should welcome a visit from the local member of parliament at any time.

I do acknowledge that this issue is very tricky, and I am delighted to say that I will have the opportunity later in the year to travel to both Iran and Finland, and refugee policy and equivalent detention systems will be the key things that our delegation will look at. You know how small our problem is when you realise that in Iran there are 1.9 million refugees, which makes our situation pale into insignificance. (Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: Rural and Regional Australia: Education and Health Policies

talk.start.para: âThe largest centre in my electorate of Parkes is an outstanding model of this government's approach to improving the lives of people in regional areas of Australia, especially in western New South Wales. On Friday, Dubbo took a huge leap towards becoming a major university centre, with confirmation that all 80 places recently allocated by the federal government to Charles Sturt University will be in the city of Dubbo. Twenty of the places are regional places and 60 have been awarded to Charles Sturt University from the Backing Australia's Ability program. It was confirmed on Friday afternoon that the 60 places from the Backing Australia's Ability program were to be based in Dubbo.

speech.para: With normal attrition rates, it is estimated that the new places will result in at least 220 additional students at the Dubbo campus over the next four years. As a result, I believe that Dubbo has just turned the corner towards being a university city and a centre of excellence for learning and education. I credit local visionaries and this government for making this huge difference. For its part, the federal government has invested heavily in this project, and the money could not have been better spent in terms of the impact this will make on people's lives in Dubbo, in the towns of the surrounding district, and in the region as a whole. The 80 new places are on top of the numbers that will already be flocking to the cityânot to mention the staff and associated positions that must follow.

As well as being a major boost to Dubbo's educational standing, this announcement will also have huge benefits in terms of the type of professionals Dubbo can attract and the economic spin-offs in the housing and hospitality industries, for example. The benefits for the broader region will be equally terrific, and the opportunity for young people in western New South Wales to study closer to home should arrest, to some degree, the flow of our best and brightest from Dubbo and the west to the metropolitan areas. I was speaking recently at the orientation at the Dubbo campus of the university, and the dean informed me that 300 people are currently undertaking a tertiary education at Charles Sturt University in Dubboâand that was before these new places were announcedâ who would not have had an opportunity to achieve a tertiary education before. That is 300 people who would not have been studying elsewhere and would not have achieved a tertiary education at all.

The Dubbo campus recently staged a Tin Shed Ball that, for most Dubbo residents, was the first high-profile student event in the city. I am sure that, as these campus occurrences continue, the reality will hit that Dubbo is no longer just the service centre to the vast western plains; it is also host to a university and everything that comes with that honour. More importantly, the consolidation of the university's operations will greatly enhance efforts to address other issues in the lives of people in the regionâmost notably health services. In conjunction with the clinical school that this government has also seen fit to locate in Dubbo, and the MRI that we hope will be announced very shortlyâdespite members nearby having different opinionsâthe framework is in place to accelerate strategies to increase the availability of health professionals in country areas like ours.

In addition to the popular scholarships that are in place to help country students become doctors and to attract city students to regional areas, the university will in future be able to use its facilities and education network to boost those objectivesâbecause, without doubt, the shortage of all manner of health professionals in western New South Wales remains a key concern for people and is the major inhibitor to the quality of life enjoyed.

I feel obliged to again point out that it is not just GPs that are chronically insufficient in numbersâ even in Dubbo; the scarcity extends to all allied health professionals: nurses, medical specialists, dentists, pharmacists, drug and alcohol counsellors and psychologists. My vision is that there is nothing that can stop us now from addressing these issues. With the cooperation that has been shown by the leaders of Charles Sturt University and Sydney University in establishing the clinical school, and with the willingness they have shown to share facilities, including administrative facilities, there is no reason that some of the courses offered by Charles Sturt University at some of its other campuses could not in the near future be extended, through technology, to Dubbo and the western region.

To be sure, the new tertiary infrastructureâalthough complemented with the new senior college for years 10 to 12 that has been funded with $9 million worth of federal assistanceâwill not result in overnight miracles. In fact, by the time the real dividends are harvested from this investment in the future, there is every chance that this government, many of the ministers, and hopefully most of the opposition, will have changed. These steps provide long-term answers that may take 10 years to have a major impactâ whether that be an increase in health professionals or a dramatic end to the brain drain and the city drift of academics and talented young peopleâwhile short-term solutions, in the form of the aforementioned bonded scholarships, will bring some benefit. For example, the number of GPs in Dubbo rose by a quarter this year compared with this time last year, due to the federally funded program that places recent graduates in country areas. I understand that there are 25 more doctors in the region under the practice placement program run by the Royal Australian College of GPs. These GPs operate out of the premises of an existing GP, who acts in a mentor role, offering the visitors experience in running a practice and a taste of country lifestyle. They are in the various towns for six-month rotations, and this is a concerted approach to addressing the shortage of GPs in rural and regional areas.

To its credit, this government has also spent huge sums of money implementing meaningful, long-term solutions that are of little political or publicity value to this government but that are undertaken because they are the right thing to do. Too often the cynical will say: `Votes are the bottom line. If you want to get the support of your MP, mention the ballot box backlash.' In this case, and others too numerous to mention, the motivation has been to get the best outcome for the community.

I mentioned earlier the red-letter status of the boost in campus numbers, and I should briefly explain the significance for those colleagues who might be unaware. Until this university campus became a reality, the 320,000 square kilometres of western New South Wales that comprise my electorate had no university. Other New South Wales centres like Armidale, Bathurst, Orange, Wagga and Albury have been able to boast of their tertiary facilities and enjoy the numerous economic, demographic and social benefits they entailâbut, alas, until recently, Dubbo could not. The vast tract of western New South Wales, for which Dubbo the largest population centre and primary service centre, lost its best and brightest every year, forced away not only to Newcastle, Sydney and Wollongong but also to other regional centres.

But this government has changed that situation for the better of all involved, and for that this government deserves recognition. What is more, this government has implemented these huge improvements with additional scope for addressing other regional concerns like health services. Make no mistake: initiatives like the university and the medical school are among the most far-reaching and beneficial initiatives that the Dubbo region has seen in my adult life. In addition to the telecommunications revolution under way out west, via the hugely successful Networking the Nation program, and the massive investment in the environment through the Natural Heritage Trust, this government has been a tonic for regional New South Wales. While work remains to be done, solutions to problems that a decade ago under Labor seemed intractable have been tackled with courage and commitment by this government.

As I mentioned, it is often said that sometimes the longer term solutions do not draw the praise that they perhaps should, but it is quite clear to any thinking person that, if these changes were implemented 10 years ago, many of the crises that we are facing today in my region simply would not be part of our lives. If the establishment of the Royal Flying Doctor base in Dubbo to service the outlying towns and provide visiting specialist services to places like Burke, Brewarrina, Cobar, Wilcannia and Tibooburra had been implemented five years ago we would not have some of the health problems that we now have in those areas. If the clinical schools that were announced in the last budget had been implemented 10 years ago, we would not have the shortage of doctors that we now have. If the Department of Rural Medicine that was established in Broken Hill by this government early in my term of governmentâit was a policy that had come from the first term of the governmentâhad not been established, there would be 60 fewer jobs in Broken Hill and the delivery of health service teaching to people who live in the Wilcannia, Burke, Brewarrina and Wanaaring areas simply would not have happened. The number of Aboriginal people who have graduated with a diploma of health sciences from the Department of Rural Health has been incredible, and it has been my great honour to have met some of these outstanding young students. As I said, the things that this government has put in place to turn around the problems faced by people who live in my area need to be recognised and the government congratulated. (Time expired)

motion.para: That grievances be noted.
