(4) Subject to subsection (5), a Registrar may, on the application of an employer, endorse a certificate issued to that employer under section 267, if the Registrar is satisfied that the employer is a practising member of a religious society or order whose doctrines or beliefs preclude membership of an organisation or body other than the religious society or order of which the employer is a member.

(5) A Registrar must not endorse a certificate under subsection (4) unless satisfied that, at the time application is made for endorsement, all of the employees employed by the applicant have agreed that the applicant's certificate should be endorsed.
(6) An application under subsection (4) may be made at the time of an application under section 267 or at any later time.
(7) The endorsement of a Registrar under subsection (4) remains in force for the period that the certificate remains in force.

quote.para: Note: A certificate issued under section 267 remains in force for the period (not exceeding 12 months) specified in the certificate, but may be renewed. A Registrar's endorsement under subsection 4 does not remain in force when a certificate is renewed, but a new application for endorsement may be made.

para.inline: Treatment of arrangements under which a person can instruct another person to acquire a financial product

quote.para: (1) In this section:
acquirer, in relation to a custodial arrangement, has the meaning given by the definition of custodial arrangement.
client, in relation to a custodial arrangement, has the meaning given by the definition of custodial arrangement.
custodial arrangement means an arrangement between a person (the provider) and another person (the client) (whether or not there are also other parties to the arrangement) under which:
(a) the client is, or is entitled, to give an instruction that a particular financial product, or a financial product of a particular kind, is to be acquired; and

(b) if the client gives such an instruction, a person (the acquirer), being the provider or a person with whom the provider has or will have an arrangement, must (subject to any discretion they have to refuse) acquire the financial product, or a financial product of that kind; and
(c) if the acquirer acquires the financial product, or a financial product of that kind, pursuant to an instruction given by the client, either:
(i) the product is to be held on trust for the client or another person nominated by the client; or

(ii) the client, or another person nominated by the client, is to have rights or benefits in relation to the product or a beneficial interest in the product, or in relation to, or calculated by reference to, dividends or other benefits derived from the product.
instruction includes a direction or request.
provider, in relation to a custodial arrangement, has the meaning given by the definition of custodial arrangement.
regulated acquisition means an acquisition of a financial product pursuant to an instruction by the client under a custodial arrangement, being an acquisition:
(a) by way of issue by the issuer (the regulated person); or
(b) pursuant to a sale by a person (the regulated person) in circumstances described in subsection 1012C(5), (6) or (8).
regulated person, in relation to a regulated acquisition of a financial product, has the meaning given by paragraph (a) or (b) (as the case requires) of the definition of regulated acquisition.

para.inline: Obligation on provider to give client a PDS

quote.para: (2) Before a regulated acquisition of a financial product occurs pursuant to an instruction given by the client under a custodial arrangement, the provider must give the client a Product Disclosure Statement for the product if a Product Disclosure Statement for the product would, if there were an equivalent direct acquisition by the client, be required by subsection 1012B(3) or 1012C(3) (see subsection (3) of this section) to be given to the client by the regulated person before that acquisition occurred. For this purpose, an equivalent direct acquisition is an acquisition that would occur if:

(a) the product were instead being offered for issue or sale direct to the client by the regulated person for the same price (or for the appropriate proportion of that price, if the transaction for the regulated acquisition also covers other products); and
(b) the circumstances of that issue or sale to the client were otherwise the same as those in which the regulated acquisition will occur.

para.inline: Determining whether a PDS would have to be given for an equivalent direct acquisition

quote.para: (3) The following provisions apply for the purpose of determining whether the regulated person would be required by subsection 1012B(3) or 1012C(3) to give the client a Product Disclosure Statement for the financial product:
(a) the effect of the provisions referred to in subsection 1012B(5) or 1012C(10), as the case requires, as they have effect subject to the following paragraphs, must be taken into account;

(b) subsections 1012D(1) and (2) apply as if references in those subsections to the regulated person's belief in relation to a matter were instead references to the provider's belief in relation to that matter;

(c) subsections 1012D(2) and (3) apply as if references to the client already holding a financial product of the same kind also included a reference to a person already holding a financial product of the same kind as a result of an instruction given by the client under a custodial arrangement;
(d) sections 1012E and 1012F are to be disregarded;
(e) section 1012G has effect in accordance with subsection (4).
(4) The following provisions apply in relation to section 1012G:

(a) in determining for the purposes of subsection (2) whether the regulated person would be required by subsection 1012B(3) or 1012C(3) to give the client a Product Disclosure Statement for the financial product, subsection 1012G(2) applies as if the reference to the client instructing the regulated person (in an issue situation) that they require the financial product to be provided or issued immediately, or by a specified time, were instead a reference to the client instructing the provider that they require the financial product to be acquired immediately, or by a specified time;

(b) if, because of subsection 1012G(2) as it applies because of paragraph (a) of this subsection, the provider does not have to give the client a Product Disclosure Statement for a financial product before a regulated acquisition of the financial product occurs pursuant to an instruction given by the client under a custodial arrangement:

(i) subsection 1012G(2) applies in relation to the provider, the client and the regulated acquisition as if the obligation it imposes to comply with subsection 1012G(3) were imposed on the provider; and

(ii) subsection 1012G(3) applies in relation to the provider, the client and the regulated acquisition as if the reference to the regulated person were instead a reference to the provider, as if subparagraph 1012G(3)(b)(i) were omitted and as if the reference in subparagraph 1012G(3)(b)(ii) to the day on which the financial product was issued or sold to the client were instead a reference to the day on which the regulated acquisition occurs.
(5) Section 1013A applies in relation to a regulated acquisition as if:

(a) paragraph 1013A(1)(b) also covered a Product Disclosure Statement that is required to be given by subsection (2) of this section in relation to an acquisition covered by paragraph (a) of the definition of regulated acquisition in subsection (1) of this section; and

(b) paragraph 1013A(2)(b) also covered a Product Disclosure Statement that is required to be given by subsection (2) of this section in relation to an acquisition covered by paragraph (b) of the definition of regulated acquisition in subsection (1) of this section.

talker.name: Hockey, Joe, MP
Mr HOCKEY
talker.role: Minister for Financial Services and Regulation

talk.start.para: âI move:

motion.para: That the amendments be agreed to.

speech.para: Again, it is just a very short process. I know that we are very short of time. The passage of the Financial Services Reform Bill 2001 and its related bills marks the implementation of the final major part of the 1997 Wallis report. It completes the major reform of the financial services industry in Australia that now represents more than seven per cent of the Australian economy and employs more than 330,000 people. The bill proposes three key reforms: a harmonised licensing disclosure and conduct framework for all financial service providers, a consistent and comparable framework for financial product disclosure, and a streamlined regulatory regime for financial markets and clearing and settlement systems. It will introduce a consistent framework of consumer protection across the financial services industry and, at the same time, it will cut compliance costs and remove regulatory barriers to the introduction of technological innovations.

This bill has been subject to widespread consultation processes over the past three years. The government is very grateful to everyone who has taken the time and the trouble to provide feedback on the provisions of the bill. The process is continuing with a current round of consultation on the draft regulations to be made under the bill. In addition, these provisions have twice been considered by the Parliament Joint Statutory Committee on Corporations and Securities. I would like to thank all the members of that committee, including the chairman, Senator Chapman, and the secretariat, for their work on the FSR Bill.

There were a number of amendments made in the Senate. Many of the amendments made by the government in the Senate were of a minor and technical nature and were intended to clarify the operation of the proposed new arrangements. A number of the amendments which were moved were the product of continued consultation between the government and stakeholders that has taken place since the introduction of the bill. The government amendments address a number of areas of concern and there are a number of issues to be dealt with. They cover the concerns of the PJC about the impact of the bill on insurance agents. The amendments made in the Senate will allow insurance agents more time to set in place arrangements for a transition into the new regime and will provide more flexibility in establishing arrangements with licensees. The amendments will clarify that contractual entitlements for remuneration will continue after the commencement of the bill. A media exemption has been inserted in the bill to ensure that media organisations will not require a licence to publish or broadcast information that falls within the definition of general financial product advice.

Finally, provisions of the bill that relate to telephone monitoring in the context of takeover bids will be narrowed so that they apply only to calls made to retail investors. This amendment will ensure that these provisions provide protection for retail investors while not impeding the activities of institutional and professional investors in the wholesale market.
Debate interrupted.

talk.start.para: âOrder! It being 10.30 p.m., I propose the question:

motion.para: That the House do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: âI wish to bring to this House's attention tonight a matter concerning the display of a large billboard advertisement on Parramatta Road near the intersection of Mosely Street, Strathfield during the months of July and August. The advertisement was for a product called Four Seasons(R) Condoms and depicted pictures of three sizes of condoms that are within that trade marked product range. I say `trade marked' by virtue of the existence of the symbol R with a circle being one of the symbols depicting a registered trademark.

speech.para: What is significant about this advertisement is the location of the billboardâthat is, it is directly adjacent to St Andrew's Anglican Church, Strathfield. The proximity of the advertisement to the church raised immediate concerns from the parish secretary, Mrs Yvonne Coorey, the parish rector, Reverend John Woo, and many parishioners. Reverend John Woo first raised the objection to the existence of the billboard with the Advertising Standards Board. I quote from the ASB's letter to Reverend Woo, dated 23 July 2001. The letter says in part:

quote.para: I should mention that it is not the role of the ASB to determine the issue of whether outdoor advertisements for condoms should or should not be permitted in this country. This is a matter for the Parliaments of Australia. You may wish to express your concerns in this regard to your local Member of Parliament.

speech.para: The situation is such that the board showed its true colours by exhibiting a definite moral standard in choosing not to answer the question of whether advertisements for condoms should or should not be permitted in this location. With respect, that is not the question. There are in fact two questions: firstly, what moral code does the Commonwealth government bring to play in the enforcement of standards in any kind in civic society; secondly, was the advertisement sensitive to public morality?

I refer to a letter on this issue from the Vice-Chancellor of the Australian Catholic University, Professor Peter Sheehan, dated 21 August 2001, addressed to me. Professor Sheehan is a person with some 20 years professional experience in censorship in Australia. He notes:

quote.para: There is a tension between prevailing public morality and the perspectives of those who are offended. I think the advertisement for condoms next to a church illustrates that tension well. To my mind, guidelines should be sensitive to such tension. The billboard shown in your material may not be explicit, but it should not have been placed there. It is an example, I am afraid, of holding legitimate moral perspectives up to public ridicule.

speech.para: I refer to the advertisement holding out that the product is a registered trademark. The ASB's letter says:

quote.para: Thank you for your letter dated 20 July 2001 complaining about an advertisement for Australian Therapeutic Supplies Pty Ltd's Four Seasons condoms.

speech.para: A reasonable person would therefore assume that Australian Therapeutic Supplies Pty Ltd was the owner of the product called Four Seasons Condoms and that this corporation was the registered trademark holder of this product. Not so, Mr Speaker. A recent search with IP Australia through a trademark examiner revealed that the words `Four Seasons' in the context of the word `condom' is actually the registered trademark of a Mr Graham William Porter.
I refer to the Australian Association of National Advertisers Code of Ethics, which has as its first code, numbered 1.1:

quote.para: Advertisements shall comply with Commonwealth law and the law of the relevant State or Territory.

speech.para: We have here a situation where the advertiser differs from the registered trademark holder of the product name. Further, the ASB is a self-regulator acting under the auspices of state government jurisdiction on the matter of advertising. The simple truth here is that there is effectively no regulation of advertising.

Following the ASB's puerile response to Reverend Woo, I tabled question on notice No. 2866 in this House on 20 August 2001. The question goes to the operation of enforcement of Commonwealth law, in this case the Trade Marks Act 1995. On the substantive issue of whether it was proper to exhibit a condom ad next to a church, the ASB morally predetermined the matter by saying all at once that the advertisement was moral, therefore licit to be exhibited. Too bad for those churchgoers or other people offended by the advertisement and/or its location. Instead, the ASB saw fit to recommend that a complainant should express their concerns in this regard to their local member of parliamentâa true cop-out, a triumph for obfuscation. In this instance, the ASB is truly holding the public to ridicule. The ASB is merely pandering to those sectional interests that would deny the existence of any regulation. They are anarcho-capitalists that would advocate no regulation at all, owing no moral obligation and no obligation at all other than to their own profit.

In this billboard case, the ASB breached its own AANA advertising standards by misleading Reverend Woo and his parishioners by implying that the advertiser and the registered trademark holder were one and the same person. Further, the ASB failed to accommodate prevailing public morality, failed to demonstrate due diligence in ensuring the said advertisement complied with Commonwealth and state law and further disparaged an alternative moral perspective.

I condemn the ASB for their obfuscation. The ASB's letter was misleading in that it implied that the registered trademark was of a person other than Australian Therapeutic Supplies Pty Ltd. In this case, I support the observations of Professor Sheehan in calling for regulations that accommodate public sensitivity in relation to the positioning of billboard advertisements. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI rise before the House this evening to bring to your attention the major significance of, and my continuing and enthusiastic support for, the proposed Outback Highway, which is destined to link Winton in Queensland with Laverton in Western Australia. This is a project that I have supported since before my election to parliament, one I spoke of in my first speech and one which I urge every member here tonight from Queensland, the Northern Territory and Western Australia to support and ensure its success.

speech.para: This highway is a 2,800-kilometre stretch through some of the most rugged and desolate country in Australia. This is untamed, unspoiled outback Australia at its best. Next year, 2002, being the Year of the Outback, it is most appropriate that attention be given to this highway. Starting at Winton, it progresses through Boulia in Queensland, to Alice Springs, Uluru and Docker River in the Northern Territory and then into my patch, through Giles, Warburton and Laverton in the Western Desert and the Northern Goldfields of Western Australia. Of the most significance is the impact it will have on the numerous Aboriginal communities along the route. Of the 2,800 kilometres, 1,700 kilometres is basic gravel road. In total, $120 million is needed for the first stage of the project to bring it up to a type 3 all-weather gravel road. Then an additional $180 million is required for the full sealing of the unsealed portions.

This is a major initiative for my electorate of Kalgoorlie, and a project that is absolutely vital for both the further development of the communities along this route and for the tourism industry of Western Australia. There is a very hardworking team of people lobbying for this highway, headed by the Chairman of the Outback Highway Development Council, Patrick Hill, of Laverton. This project has the support of the shires, the Aboriginal communities and the towns within regional Australia which will ultimately benefit through the provision of increased services, better cost-effective transport options, employment opportunities, resource and trade developments and much, much more.

The project will have benefits for the communities on the Outback Highway route, certainly, but, of far more importance, the people of Kalgoorlie-Boulder say it will be a vital tourism route that will link the Stockman's Hall of Fame in Queensland with the soon to be opened Prospectors and Miners Hall of Fame in Kalgoorlie-Boulder. In addition, the highway will also have significant benefits for the tourism, transport and trade industries in other Western Australian areas. It is just as important for the mid-west and Gascoyne, the Pilbara and the south-east down to Esperance as it is to Kalgoorlie-Boulder. Local government in all of these regions are supportive of this, as are the shires and councils throughout Queensland.

This is most likely one of the most advantageous projects that we as a government can support. It will provide peopleâin particular, indigenous people in remote Central Australia and the Western Desertâwith a better quality of life. It is a project which captured the support of the past Western Australian government, which committed $25 million over a 10-year period. Whether this will be honoured by the new Labor government is not known.

In the Northern Territory, the Labor Party promised $40 million over two terms. I would hope that this is not a promise they will break. Queensland has committed itself to $400,000 per year for four years. The Outback Highway Development Council will be lobbying this federal government for funds, and I believe significant support should be givenâand this support matched by the state governments. The council do have an application for funds, under the coalition government's excellent Regional Solutions program, due to be determined in the next few weeks. I would urge that this application be treated favourably. The application is for $462,000 for a second feasibility study, which will focus on five areas: engineering, environmental, social, economic and cultural areas. At the moment, there are only two reliable east-west road links: the Eyre Highway along the southern regions, and the Victoria Highway across the Kimberley in WA and the Northern Territory. I urge every member here tonight to support this third strategic link and help make this outstanding vision a reality.

talk.start.para: âI take this opportunity to raise a matter which has been of great concern to my electorate, and that is the effect of the Howard government's implementation of national competition policy. I know that I am not alone in my concern about the effect of this issue on my electorate: communities around the country are demonstrating their objection to the narrow and unfair interpretation of this policy put upon them.

speech.para: The Labor Party recognised the need for reform in this area in their last term in office. The Hilmer report in 1993, combined with the full consideration of this issue through the Council of Australian Governments, led to the 1995 COAG agreement, which outlined the new national competition policy. This policy was based on the recognition that lack of competition in certain sectors can impose burdens on consumers through high prices, poor services and a lack of choice, and can affect Australia's international competitiveness. Areas such as rail, shipping, water and electricity were targets of this reform.

The effects of this policy were supposed to make prices fairer and to introduce benefits to the economy and to the community. Most importantly, national competition policy must serve the public interest, and this is where the Howard government's interpretation of this policy is wrong. When introducing national competition policy legislation to parliament in 1995, Labor made it clear that:

quote.para: It is important to understand that this government is not interested in reform or competition for its own sake. The package recognises that economic efficiency is one element of a broader public policy context which also includes social considerations. Explicit recognition is given to these broader elements of the public interest in the Bill and in the competition principles agreements.

speech.para: Unfortunately, under the Howard government this crucial element of this policyâcommunity interestâ has been all but ignored. The government has applied national competition policy in a way that is often lacking in community involvement, with little regard for public interest and without adequate consideration of its impact on employment or regional development.

Unfortunately, yet again rural and regional Australia have been the losers in this government's city-centric approach. Rural and regional Australia's cries for a fair go are simply not heard by this Prime Minister. The pain that they experience is ignored. This brings me to an example from my own electorate, where the application of this policy has caused an unfair burden to be placed on the people of Launceston in relation to their water rates. Under national competition policy, the Launceston City Council recently introduced a user-pays system for water usage in Launceston, and the people in Launceston have been particularly outraged. My office has been flooded with calls from people who are very concerned about this new charge and, everywhere I go, I encounter community-run petitions.

It is not that people in Launceston are not willing to make a fair contribution to the cost of the water; it is just that they object to paying something that their neighbours in the next shire do not have to pay. The object of national competition policy was to make prices fairer for people; it is hardly fairer if neighbours do not have the same situation. To say that a private operator could supply water to the people of Launceston and thereby compete with Launceston City Council appears somewhat ridiculous. Again, it is people in Sydney and Melbourne thinking that the rest of the country have the same needs and, indeed, service opportunities as they have. Well, they do not.

The people of north-east Tasmania have their own needs and they are fed up with being disadvantaged because of their regional status. The Howard government must take responsibility for the pain it has inflicted on these communities. The Howard government seems quite happy to let national competition policy run rife, without giving a thought to the impact on Australian communities. Under a Labor government, national competition policy could serve the purpose for which it was intended. Labor would ensure that national competition policy was applied in a way that was actually of benefit to all communities.

National competition policy must be closely overseen by the government to ensure that the community is involved and has control of the process. Most importantly, Labor will re-establish the critical role of the public interest test and work to ensure that it is fairly applied and is consistent in every application of national competition policy. This test must accurately reflect the concerns of the community in which it is applied.

Labor will also work to make the National Competition Council more representative of all Australians, not just of those people who happen to reside in major metropolitan centres. I call on the government to take immediate steps to address the unfair application of this policy, introduce a clear and transparent public interest test and stop placing an unfair burden on the people of rural and regional Australia.

talk.start.para: âI would like to make a few remarks about a special place in my electorateâthat is, Bondi. Bondi has a special meaning to the Australian ear. It speaks of something very peculiar to this country. We are blessed not only with a harsh and unforgiving interior geography but also with perhaps the most welcoming coastline in the world. Bondiâto me and, I think, to a lot of peopleâmeans the right of every Australian to swim in the surf where there is a bright and clean expanse of soft sand and to enjoy ourselves in this way and be very proud of it.

speech.para: But Bondi is also home to a great variety of people and that, too, is an important metaphor for modern Australia. In Bondi you find all sorts of people: orthodox Jewish families, young backpackers, ex-wharfies, judges, doctors, bankers, jockeys, some Muslim families, union men, politicians, the odd crim, surfie chicks, dope smokers, journalists, actors, directors, models, writers, a few people of Maori descent and, occasionally, the odd little Eurasian girl splashing in the shallows on a hot summer's day. But what matters most in Bondi is that you live and let live. That is really the essence of this country, in my mind: the ease of living that depends on being good neighbours and even on trying to see the best in people who come from a background that is very different from your own.

It makes me very sad to see, reported in the newspapers this weekend, that a candidate in the forthcoming election in my electorate has lapsed into some very unfortunate language about Maori people. Let me be very clear about this: nobody in Bondi is a `plague'. No-one on the basis of their race deserves comparison with the evil of drugs: today it might be Maoris, but tomorrow it will be Asians, and then it will be Jews after that. It should be remembered that words like `plague', `germs', `subhuman', `scum' and so forth were the sorts of epithets that were used in Nazi Germany to demonise Jewish people. I hope that we never hear words like `plague' uttered about people in Bondi ever again.

talk.start.para: âTonight the Procedure Committee tabled a report titled Balancing tradition and progress: procedures for the opening of parliament, and I wish to comment about some of the issues that were raised in the committee's report. In discussing their recommendations for the procedures for the opening of parliament, they indicate the need for this parliament to be very much a contemporary organisation, an organisation that reflects that we are an institution in the 21st century.

speech.para: One of the proposalsâand I think it is important that it be paraphrased in the words of the committee, where they say `first people, people first'âis that the ceremony should start with a smoking ceremony in the forecourt of Parliament House, indicating the depth and strength that we should place upon the contribution of our indigenous people. The other aspect is that the Governor-General's speech should be made to an assembled gathering in the Great Hall where senators and members of the House of Representatives could join together with the people of Australia as a contribution to the opening ceremony. In a pre-emptory article about the committee's report in this morning's Age, a section of the submission of the former Governor-General, Bill Hayden, was quoted, where he said:

quote.para: The Great Hall lacks the aura, the prestige and solemnity for an occasion such as the address by the governor-general for the opening of the parliament that is provided by the exclusive environment of the Senate.

speech.para: I think the former Governor-General is wrong. Harris, Fowler and Wright in House of Representatives Practice state:

quote.para: Directly beyond the Foyer is the Great Hall, the venue of parliamentary ceremonies and receptions, occasions of national significance and other functions.

speech.para: The Great Hall is one of the great spaces of this Parliament House. It has that wonderful tapestry of Arthur Boyd's painting of the Shoalhaven. It is a very important space in this place, and the former Governor-General should be reminded of that. It was the place in May 1988 where the Queen actually opened the building. It is part of the history of this building. It is an important aspect of Australia's way of life, and it is appropriate that it should be seen as a gathering place where the people of Australia can be involved in the opening of this parliament. Using the Great Hall would be an attempt to make sure that the proceedings of this parliament were relevant to all.

Another recommendation of the committee is that we look at ways in which the oath that is administered to members at the opening of the parliament may be made more contemporary. The recommendation indicates that it should include recognition of the people of Australia. Any member who has attended a citizenship ceremony since the change to the new pledge of commitment would know how powerful the words are that we ask new Australians to pledge. We ask them to pledge:

quote.para: From this time forward, (under God) I pledge my loyalty to Australia and its people, whose democratic beliefs I share, whose rights and liberties I respect, and whose laws I will uphold and obey.

speech.para: A very powerful change has been made to the way in which we view the way we are coming together as Australian citizens.

There are many ways in which we can make the parliament a better, more contemporary place. The conduct of question time is something that we could reflect upon. Mr Speaker, I know that your job in the chair is a very difficult one and that the standing orders are couched in a way that gives the government of the day the majority. Look at question time today, for instance, and, firstly, the dorothy dixer question to the Treasurer about the NATSEM study. As an opposition member, I yearn for some opportunity to be able to debate what the Treasurer said in his answerâto reflect upon the fact that disposable income is not the only test; that those things that families have to spend their money on are important. Secondly, we could look at the way in which one minister understandably used the opportunity of a question to give an answer that should have been a ministerial statement, while another minister continually used the opportunity to give a ministerial statement in the guise of an answer. It is no reflection on the chamber that that practice has developed and become allowed, but I think we as members of this House have to recognise that people out there in viewing the proceedings are questioning these things, and we should look at them to ensure that our procedures are contemporary. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âThe coalition government has worked hard to give Australian consumers a better deal by dismantling the barriers to parallel importing on a number of products, such as CDs. The changes were brought about in part by the recommendations of the consumers' friend, Professor Allan Fels, and the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission. But there has been strong resistance from the Labor Party and some other quarters to extending this benefit to other products, such as books and computer software.

speech.para: I wish to use the opportunity of this debate to briefly comment on the distorted arguments put forward by one of those critics of parallel importing, Hilary McPhee. In an article in the Age on 18 May, Ms McPhee gave scant regard to the welfare of Australian readers. Ms McPhee's article advocated restrictions on parallel importing in Australia by referring to the Japanese government's restrictions on imported rice. Rice is culture, she said, and protecting Japanese rice is in the national interest. I assume from this that restrictions on the import of overseas books are protecting Australian culture and in the national interest. Has Ms McPhee asked Australian rice growers what they think of Japanese barriers to rice imports? They have gained a toehold in the market but, because of the development of rice varieties that appeal to Japanese palates and much lower production costs, they deserve greater market access. In Japan the rice consumer is almost defenceless against the political muscle of rice growers and the rest of the farm lobby.

Ms McPhee says we need more competition, not less, `but as far as possible in our terms'. This hints at a contradiction. It is hardly competition if it is `in our terms', because we are not really competing but dictating market conditions. Readers have rights as well as authors and publishers, but they tend to get scant regard from those with a vested interest in retaining the current copyright laws that restrict the entry of overseas books. Restrictions allow higher prices to be charged for the protected product than would otherwise be the case. Foreign copyright holders are the prime beneficiaries. Australian readers pay more and, when imports of technical books and computer software are restricted, Australian industry bears a higher cost and this flows on to consumers.

Not long ago Australians lived in a highly protected economy where inefficient industries sheltered behind high tariff walls. You, Mr Speaker, had your own battles in your own electorate with particular issues to do with high tariffs, and you fought them and led on the issue. Many `infant' industries the object of protection failed to mature into productive adults. We had high cost industry and unsatisfactory working and management practices that burdened export industries with high cost structures, making them less competitive. Few would argue that Australia is not better off today after substantial reform of trade policy. We have become far more competitive because we seek greater productivity rather than handouts or protection from government. Companies, including publishers, who operate in a competitive environment are under pressure to innovate and export.

A hoary old argument frequently raised is that relaxing laws on importing books is a threat to Australian culture. It is never clearly explained why this is so or what exactly is our literary culture. Our best writers are published abroadâsome books with an Australian culture, but others with universal themes. Has the importation of books and plays by writers such as Gore Vidal, Salman Rushdie or Tom Wolfe adversely affected Australian culture? According to the June 2000 report on parallel importing by the Intellectual Property and Competition Review Committee, removing import restrictions does not undermine the efficacy of copyright as a stimulus to creativity. The report noted that within the European Community restrictions on parallel importing are prohibited. This ensures that even the smaller European economies can benefit from intense competition, low prices and the extended product range that a large integrated market brings. Removing the restrictions will provide Australia with the same benefits that other economies secure through their far larger internal markets.

With import restrictions in place, the owners of copyrighted material have the power to charge higher prices to Australian consumers than would otherwise be the case. In addition, the suppliers of copyright material are getting fewer because of international mergers by publishing houses and, with less competition, prices generally remain higher. Hilary McPhee and the Labor Party should consider whether it is proper to deny Australians cheaper books while overseas writers and publishers reap the benefit. It was overseas publishers who first proposed import restrictions, and this was not in the interests of the Australian industry or Australian readers.

talk.start.para: âThis is an unexpected opportunity, but in the last few minutes available to me I would like to do two things. The first is possibly a little self-indulgent, but I wish to extend to my father a happy 65th birthday today. I know you, Mr Speaker, served in this place with him, as did the member for Scullin. I can report to the House that my father is alive and well and still living happily with my mother, Anne, in Cessnock.

speech.para: The second matter I want to raise is my very deep concern about national highway funding. I have raised on a number of occasions two very important road projects in my electorate. One is the project known as the Kurri Corridor, which would link the F3 Freeway to the New England Highway, north of Branxton. The other is an intersection where the New England Highway meets Weakleys Drive and Thornton Road. Both these projects are very important. I learned with some distress just last week that on the web site of the Minister for Transport and Regional Services is a statement that all national highway funding and all roads of national importance funding have been committed for the next three years.

The two road projects I have just nominated are already well behind schedule because of national highway budget cuts over the last three, four or even five years. The web site message indicates to me that, under the government's current program, those two important road projects stand no chance of getting funding for at least the next threeyears. As I said, they are very important road projects in my electorate, both in economic transport terms and in safety terms, and they are very important to both the Lower and Upper Hunter. It is disappointing me greatly that the Howard government continues to reject these very important projects.

It being 11 p.m., the debate is interrupted.

debate.para: The following answers to questions were circulated:

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Health and Aged Care, upon notice, on 30 November 2000:

quote.para: (1) Did he receive the necessary supporting documentation from the NSW Government in August 1999 for the provision of a magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scanner for Liverpool Hospital under the Federal Adjustment and Relocation Scheme.
(2) Did he state in a press release dated 23 December 1998 that subject to the supporting documentation, he expected the hospital to have an MRI as soon as possible.
(3) Has he delayed the approval of funding for an MRI scanner for Liverpool Hospital under the Scheme; if so, why.
(4) When will he approve funding for an MRI scanner at Liverpool Hospital.

talker.name: Wooldridge, Dr Michael, MP
Dr Wooldridge
talker.role: Minister for Health and Aged Care

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) No. An application was provided to the Department, however it did not meet the full eligibility criteria.
(2) Yes.

(3) No. Despite the issue of the MRI Adjustment and Relocation Scheme being put on hold pending the outcome of the Blandford Review of MRI, the funding would not have been approved, as the application did not meet the necessary eligibility criteria.

(4) I have recently appointed the MRI Monitoring and Evaluation Group. Part of their charter is to revise the original Adjustment and Relocation Scheme in order to provide incentives for eligible MRI units to be relocated to tertiary referral hospitals without one. The Blandford MRI Review also recommended that up to seven additional units be recognised for eligibility. These are to be located in areas that are comparatively under-serviced and a tendering process will be used to determine these locations. While the specific criteria have not yet been established, Liverpool Hospital may well qualify under one or both of the schemes outlined above.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Health and Aged Care, upon notice, on 4 December 2000:

quote.para: (1) Has his attention been drawn to the recent report by the international health care coalition, Health Care Without Harm, into the possible health risks to newborns of exposure to chemicals such as ethylhexyl phthalate (DEHP), a chemical found in polyvinyl chloride (PVC) medical products.
(2) Are neonatal intensive care units aware of the possible risks of such PVC exposure to newborns and will these intensive care units be seeking to reduce the exposure.
(3) Will he be requesting further research into the possible risks to newborns of such PVC exposure.

talker.name: Wooldridge, Dr Michael, MP
Dr Wooldridge
talker.role: Minister for Health and Aged Care

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) Scientific staff of the Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA) have been monitoring reports published in recent months on potential health concerns relating to phthalate plasticisers used in soft PVC products. This has included the recent report of the Health Care Without Harm (HCWH) coalition, whose October 2000 report was released in conjunction with public hearings held by the European Commission into environmental and health concerns associated with PVC products. These investigations have been focussed particularly on the potential for children to be exposed to phthalate plasticisers in soft PVC toys and other situations where relatively high exposures may be possible.

The issues of main concern relate to the potential for phthalate plasticisers to affect the developing reproductive system of mammals. Such effects have been clearly shown in tests in rodents, although the exposure levels needed to produce these effects are relatively high in comparison with likely human exposures. There is also some doubt that rodents are a good qualitative predictor of the risk to humans, since other studies suggest that primates may be more resistant to these toxic effects of phthalates.

It is noted that a number of evaluations of these data have been undertaken in recent years. Contrary to the conclusions of the HCWH report, a US Panel chaired by Everett Koop, a former US Surgeon General, reported in June 1999 that there appeared to be no significant health risks associated with current uses of phthalate plasticisers.

At this time, there has been no regulatory action taken in the United States or Europe to limit the use of phthalates in soft plastics, although it is noted that plastics manufacturers are voluntarily investigating the introduction of alternative plasticisers in soft PVC toys and medical products. It is important that when new plasticisers are used in such products, their use is supported by extensive safety data which demonstrate that they are really safer than the phthalates which they will replace.

(2) Given that evidence of risk is inconclusive, there has been no regulatory response proposed in Australia to date. Neonatal Intensive Care Units are the responsibility of State and Territory governments, and I am, therefore, not able to say if they have received any advice regarding the use of plastic products softened with phthalate plasticisers.
(3) Scientific staff of the TGA will continue to monitor research findings from overseas and any regulatory actions taken by comparable countries.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Health and Aged Care, upon notice, on 7 December 2000:

quote.para: (1) Why is ReVia (Naltrexone) listed on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Schedule only to treat those afflicted with alcohol addiction.
(2) Will ReVia (Naltrexone) be reconsidered for listing on the PBS for treatment of opioid addictions.

(3) Has his attention been drawn to a Media Release from Orphan Australia, dated 11 December 1999 titled `Naltrexone wins PBS Listing - but only for alcohol addiction' which states that surveillance figures on heroin deaths found that the only State where deaths are not increasing is WA, where the population-based naltrexone program run by Dr George O'Neil appears to be making a difference.
(4) Does he accept that ReVia (Naltrexone) is the most successful method of treating opioid addiction in Australia at present; if not, what is the most successful method of treating opioid addiction.

talker.name: Wooldridge, Dr Michael, MP
Dr Wooldridge
talker.role: Minister for Health and Aged Care

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) The Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee (PBAC) considered at its July 1999 and December 1999 meetings whether ReVia (Naltrexone) should be made available:
(a) for use in the treatment of alcohol dependence within a comprehensive treatment program; and
(b) for the maintenance of formerly opioid-dependent patients who have stopped taking opioids.

Based on a large body of detailed clinical and economic data submitted by the manufacturer, the PBAC concluded that listing of Naltrexone as a pharmaceutical benefit for the treatment of alcohol dependence was justified. However, in treating opioid dependence, there was no evidence of significant efficacy based on relapse and retention rates. Coupled with major concerns about the toxicity of Naltrexone and its relatively high cost, the PBAC declined to recommend listing of the drug as a pharmaceutical benefit for this latter indication. The Government is unable to list a drug as a pharmaceutical benefit in the absence of a positive recommendation from the PBAC.
(2) Naltrexone is not expected to be reconsidered for listing as a pharmaceutical benefit unless or until the manufacturer submits further data for the PBAC's consideration.
(3) Yes.

(4) No. As is the case with many health conditions, it is not possible to develop a `one size fits all' model of treatment for opioid dependence. Different treatment options work for different users. Individual patient factors and the quality of individual treatment settings have critical impact on the effectiveness of any treatment.

Research conducted by the National Drug and Alcohol Research Centre in Sydney indicates that the most effective available treatments for heroin addiction involve drug replacement therapy supported by specialised psychotherapeutic or counselling programs. Presently, methadone maintenance is the best researched and most widely used of all currently available treatment options for opiate-dependent individuals.

subdebateinfo.title: Detention Centres: Death of Mr Mohammad Saleh
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2838)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 8 August 2001:

quote.para: (1) Has his attention been drawn to the recent death from pancreatic cancer of an asylum seeker in Western Australia.
(2) Why was the detainee admitted to Hollywood Private Hospital rather than a public facility.
(3) Was the detainee kept under ACM surveillance during his hospitalisation.
(4) Were the ACM officers involved in providing 24 hour surveillance.
(5) Were local ACM officers assigned to monitor the detainee or were officers relocated from elsewhere in Australia.
(6) What was the cost of maintaining surveillance while this detainee was hospitalised.
(7) What was the cost of medical services provided to the detainee prior to his death.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr Ruddock
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs and Minister for Reconciliation and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) My Department has advised me of the death of Mr Mohammad Saleh. Mr Saleh was detained at the Port Hedland Immigration Reception and Processing Centre (IRPC) on 12 October 2000 as an unauthorised arrival. He died at the Hollywood Private Hospital in Perth on 23 June 2001 during surgery. A preliminary report by the Coroner has indicated that the âcause of death was Gastro-intestinal Haemorrhage due to penetration of Aorta by Mediastrial Abscess Associated with Dehiscence of Surgical Anastomosisâ.

(2) Mr Saleh was admitted to the mental health clinic of the Hollywood Private Hospital Perth on 5 April 2001, primarily for the treatment of a severe depressive disorder. I am advised that Hollywood Hospital was the only mental facility with available bedspace at the time. Graylands, the closest available public mental health facility had no bedspace for Mr Saleh at the time. I would note that prior to admission, Mr Saleh had been treated for left sided abdominal discomfort and stomach pain at the Port Hedland IRPC medical centre. In the course of admission, results of a barium meal that was conducted earlier on 5 April 2001 indicated the presence of a mass in Mr Saleh's stomach. An endoscopy test later confirmed the results of the barium meal. After numerous gastroenterological opinions and procedures and a surgical opinion, it was recommended that Mr Saleh should undergo significant abdominal surgery.
(3) Yes.
(4) Yes.

(5) ACM has advised that officers were drawn from the Port Hedland IRPC to provide initial bedwatch services. Detention Officers from the Perth Immigration Detention Centre arrived later to provide these services throughout the deceased's period of hospitalisation.

(6) I am advised that the cost of providing bedwatch services during the deceased's period of hospitalisation is yet to be finalised, though it is expected to be in the order of $39,700.00 in salaries and $5,000.00 in transportation and accommodation costs.

(7) I am advised that the cost of medical services provided to the deceased prior to his death has not been fully determined, though it is expected to be in the order of $35,000. ACM has not yet received all invoices relating to the deceased's medical treatments.
